headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's First Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco, and Mr. Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. Mr.
componenttext: Welcome to Invesco's First Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco, and Mr. Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Flanagan, you may now begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much. This is Marty Flanagan, and I'm here with Loren, and we'll be speaking to the presentation that's available on the website, if you're so inclined to follow. We'll review the business, give an update on the Morgan Stanley Van Ka
componenttext:
Great. Thank you very much. This is Marty Flanagan, and I'm here with Loren, and we'll be speaking to the presentation that's available on the website, if you're so inclined to follow. We'll review the business, give an update on the Morgan Stanley Van Kampen combination, Loren will go into the financial results and then we'll open it up to Q&A.
So just to start with, if you'd take a quick overview look at the quarter, it was a strong quarter; continued strength in investment results; further improvement in net flows. It was the strongest quarter of net flows we've had since the fourth quarter of the year 2000, so quite a period. Strong operating results offset by foreign exchange and also an industry trend away from money market funds. And the high-level update on Van Kampen, we expect -- the Van Kampen Morgan Stanley we expect to close on June 1, and we'll get into some details of our revised synergies which are meaningfully better than our initial thoughts.
So with that, if you’d take a look, I'd like to do a quick summary of the results. We ended March 31 with $419 billion in Assets under management. That was down from $423 billion in the prior quarter. What that resulted in, obviously, was a slight decrease in operating income first quarter versus fourth quarter, down 2.6%. During the quarter, we were very disciplined on the expense side of the business with a decrease in revenue. What we're able to do was have a margin of 33.6% versus 33.2% in the fourth quarter last year. Also during the first quarter, the dividend will be $0.11 per share, which is a 7.2% increase versus the fourth quarter of last year.
So if we take a look at the flows, on the next page you can see gross flows were $21 billion and you can see that. Just the increase in gross flows is really what's leading the improvement in net flows. Our long-term net flows were $3.7 billion. It represents the fifth consecutive quarter of positive flows from Invesco. And as I mentioned, it's the best quarter of net flows since the fourth quarter of the year 2000. And what we are seeing across the industry in the money fund business is that low yield and people seeking yield and greater returns, continue to have outflows in money funds moving; still tends to be right now into fixed income products. That said, our money funds seem to just do a very, very good job, a high-quality team.
Taking a look at flows by the different channels, what you'll see largely from this quarter, it was gross sales in the institutional channel that was a real contributor to positive overall flows for Invesco. During the quarter, IVR, which is the mortgage capital closed-end fund that has been in the market for over a year now, they had a capital raise in January, raising $171 million. And a press release just went out this morning, they just raised another $185 million just as of last night, just got priced last night.
Also on Tuesday, we announced the final close of the Mortgage Recovery Fund. This is the fund that's part of the U.S. Treasury’s PPIP program. We closed the fund with $1.46 billion of equity commitment, and it's performing very, very well. So that's all good news for us. 
The Retail business continues to perform well. As I said, it's the fifth quarter of positive flows. We saw strong net flows in the U.K., Europe and the United States. And also, the Private Wealth Management had its 12th quarter of net inflows also.
Taking a look at high-level performance, what you'll see again is on a three-year basis, very strong, with 73% of the Assets under management being peers; five years, 78%. The one-year number was weaker than three and five years. Largely what's happened in that March-to-March period, when there was that rally, we have been conservatively positioned in our portfolios. And as you would imagine, in a rally like that, we would tend to underperform. That said, the teams are doing very, very well and very focused on their investment disciplines. And as always, the very detailed charts of performance area-by-area are in the appendix of this presentation.
Of the next page, just a couple of areas where I highlight performance. Invesco Aim continues to have strong performance. The Morningstar ratings are near the highest level since year 2000. Lipper, in Canada, awarded Invesco Trimark the Group Equity Award for the last three-year period, which is good, and you're also seeing the short-term performance improve strongly there. 
65% of Invesco Asia-Pacific assets remain above their long-term benchmarks. Invesco Perpetual, again, had very strong long-term performance, 94% of the assets beating peers over a five-year period. And continued strength and performance in the Quantitative Strategies, Global Equity, and within the Fixed Income area, cash, high-yield and muni bonds in particular.
So with that, I'd like to move into an update of the Morgan Stanley Van Kampen combination, and those that are following, it's Page 11 that I'm on right now. And from just the initial announcement, we talked that the combination aligns very well for a long-term strategic direction, and it meets all our acquisition criteria for combinations. We view the combination as a real opportunity to enhance already our very, very strong investment management teams, expanding the depth and breadth of our investment strategies and the vehicles that we can offer clients really give us a very, very broad capability to meet our client's needs. And then finally, there’s just a tremendous opportunity for us to deepen our relationship with clients and just have a much stronger distribution capability.
So a quick update on the combination. So June 1 is coming quickly. Our focus is very much to be effective from that day forward. And as we've learned more about the business, you'll see we've revised our synergies based on that and they are meaningfully stronger than what we thought originally. But we are on track for a June 1 close. 
Let me give you some highlights of that, to give you a sense of that. You'll see that the investment teams are obviously fully resourced. Our focus has been to make sure that they are not diverted at all, that they can continue to focus on managing their portfolios. The combined sales teams will provide very broad, deep coverage to all the channels in the United States here, following our top clients also. They are currently undergoing very intensive cross training across the product lineups. The overall structure of the business is in place and they’re communicated. We have very extensive plans to make sure that our colleagues at Morgan Stanley Van Kampen, when they transition over on June 1, they're up and running and effective.
Also on track is the operation IT efforts. The global operating platform will be in place. We’ll have that at close, and the transfer agency for the U.S. Mutual Fund business will also be converted at close. So again, you can tell our absolute focus has been making sure of a timely close on June 1, that we begin to offer benefits to our clients and shareholders and the people at the organization. So I'd say we have good news on that front.
So let's spend a minute on some of the momentum within Morgan Stanley Van Kampen. As you can see, if you follow the assets full-forward, at the time of the combination, Morgan Stanley Van Kampen had about $119 billion under management; at the end of March, $123 billion in Assets under management. You'll also note that in Q4 last year, there was approximately $2.8 billion in outflows. In the first quarter of this year, it's about .7, $700 million in outflow. So an improving higher assets and an improving flow trend.
What also, though, is extremely impressive and obviously important, if you look at the relative investment performance over one, three and five years, at September 30, ’09 was very strong, at 69%, 72% and 73%, one through five years. Now if you look at what the investment teams have done, the one-year, literally 88% of the portfolios are beating peers, three years, 79%; five years, 77%. So really very, very strong as we get close to the combination.
The other thing that we wanted to do was be responsive to what does the organization look like, how does it match up against industry trends, so as the analyst community is thinking about how successful could we be. And so what we want to do is highlight a couple of areas. One of the market shifts that we anticipate happening is that there’s going to be increased demand for U.S. equities and international equities. And all of us are keenly aware, if you look at the last 12 months, it’s literally only been 17% of the flows going into equities in the U.S. mutual fund market.
So how do we look after close? Literally, 63% of our retail assets will be in equities. There is also, if you look at the relative performance, it is very, very strong for U.S. and international equities. 80% of the international global assets are rated four- and five-star by Morningstar, 97% of the domestic core assets are four- and five-star rated, 66% of the equity AUMs are four- and five-star rated. So if you believe there’s going to be a movement towards equities, we are positioned very, very well. Also, there’s probably going to be increased demand for munies, and you also know that with the combined firm, muni position is going to be very strong, too.
We all know the growing opportunity in the retirement market. The firm becomes very well positioned against that with $56 billion in DC assets, strong distribution coverage, strong range of not just investment capabilities, but packaging into that marketplace. 
The other area is growing demand for ETFs and structured products. Be the fourth largest ETF provider with $50 billion in ETFs. What comes into this transaction also is Van Kampen has a new IT business. They are the second largest in the industry, and it is a very specific structured product capability that is attractive to a group of advisers. And that is going to, again, be an additional factor for us as we move forward. 
And then finally, increasing focus within the distribution landscape. Again, I think all of us are keenly aware that the top five broker/dealer organizations, top five planners are just becoming stronger and stronger. We end up being a leading partner with these very important distribution channels. And again, the depth and breadth of our coverage is really quite strong in these channels.
So that's the backdrop of some trends that we see happening and how we match up against it. So if you move on to Page 16, what we do want to do is give you an update on the accretion dilution synergies there that we’ve talked about. 
Originally when we came forward, we thought it'd be $0.13 a share in the first year from what we had known at the time of the signing of the transaction. What we’d like to do is first talk about the areas that we can control. So when you look at expense synergies, our estimate now is $80 million, $85 million. In the first year, that's up from what was $70 million and is still largely in the areas that we talked about, product streamlining, properties, and moving to the single operating platform. When we move to a steady state, what that translates into in year two is $90 million to $95 million a year in expense savings.
The other area that we’d update is really whether the – the flow attrition from this combination. Originally we thought it would be about $10 billion out. We now think it will be about $5 billion out. 
Now moving into the area, underlying – these are stated assumptions, areas that we can’t control that relates to the market and the flows. So our base assumption is that markets will go to a normal state. And with that, we think blended return between equity and fixed income is 6%. That's one of the key assumptions. 
The other key assumption is that with respect to flows for the Van Kampen business, whether net outflows now, in the second year we think the punch ratio –- the punch ratio that we use at 3.4%. What that translates into is what was $0.13 a share at the end of the first year after the closing it’s $0.17 a share; after the second year, $0.19 a share. So a meaningful increase from what we had previously discussed.
If you flip the page, just to give you an update on where we are on timing, we’re just about done with Phase I. It’s well on track, as I outlined. All indications we’re going to close on June 1. What we will then do is very quickly, as an organization, get very focused on consideration of product changes, mergers and the like. Once management makes a set of recommendations, they must be evaluated and approved by the fund board. And that's a very, very diligent process that is gone through. After the fund board’s approved that, it goes to shareholders. And we think that process will take 9 to 12 months. And after that period, we will be, what we would say, is a steady state, moving forward as we operate.
So collectively, we feel that Invesco and Morgan Stanley Van Kampen, the combination, is a much stronger organization. Clients are that much better off. Employees are going to be better off. Shareholders are going to be better off. We think this is going to be a great combination. We’re very excited about it and, literally, across all the areas that you consider, we think we are in a better position. So I'm going to stop there and turn it over to Loren.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Marty. During the quarter, you'll see that we saw continued momentum, as Marty mentioned, in our long-term net flows, also market gains but offset by net outflows in our money market funds and, notably, some unfavorable foreign exchange,
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Marty. During the quarter, you'll see that we saw continued momentum, as Marty mentioned, in our long-term net flows, also market gains but offset by net outflows in our money market funds and, notably, some unfavorable foreign exchange, resulting in a $3.5 billion decline in our AUM.
We ended the quarter with $419.6 billion in AUM. That’s down .8% since end of December. And the average AUM also declined marginally by .6% to $417.6 billion, primarily the result of the quarter-over-quarter declines and the performance fees and transaction fees, which we’ll talk about a little later. You'll see that our net revenue yield in Q1 declined by 1.7 basis points, and also we had a small impact to day count in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter.
So now let’s turn to the operating results. As we indicated previously in our March 12 8-K filing, we have expanded our non-GAAP financial measures, hopefully to improve the transparency of our core business, given the required adoption of FAS [Financial Accounting Standards Board] 167, which we’ve talked about in the past. And we had to adopt this in Q1. But also to reflect the impact of the pending Morgan Stanley Van Kampen combination. And the operating results that we’re showing here reflect this new non-GAAP presentation.
You'll see that net revenues declined $21.4 million, about 2.8% quarter-over-quarter. Unfavorable movements in the foreign exchange rates resulted in about $7 million of this decrease. And drilling down onto this aggregate number, you'll see that investment management fees fell by 1.7% to about $7.8 million, and that was, again, primarily due to the negative impact of foreign exchange, largely the depreciation of the British pound against the U.S. dollar and also fewer revenue earning days in Q1 versus Q4, which is 90 versus 92.
Service and distribution revenue increased quarter-over-quarter by 1%. This was despite the decline in average AUM. As we mentioned on our fourth quarter call, certain annual fund expense recovery limits were reached in Canada, resulting in lower than expected revenues for the fourth quarter. Performance fees in Q4 came in at $1.4 million and that was a reduction of $5.4 million quarter-over-quarter. And you’ll also see that other revenues fell by $6.6 million to $11.3 million as a result of lower transaction commissions within our real estate and private equity businesses. You'll remember that we provided a slide in Q4 that highlighted the potential for lower performance fees and other revenues in Q1. And I will emphasize, however, that they remain very difficult to forecast still.
Third-party distribution, service and advisory expenses declined marginally, .2%, in line with lower investment management and service and division fees. 
And moving on down the slide, moving to expenses, you'll see that adjusted operating expenses of $361 million declined quarter-over-quarter by $16.5 million or 4.4%. The primary driver of this reduction was lower compensation expense, however, that was combined with foreign exchange. FX reduced our adjusted operating expenses by $6 million, 16.5. 
Our employee compensation expenses decreased by $11 million or 4.2% versus the fourth quarter. This $11 million decline is explained by two factors. First, there was about $8 million of unusual expenses in Q4, as you’ll remember, which included a pension charge and some payroll taxes related to the vesting of certain large stock grants. And the second phase was $3.5 million of compensation reduction due primarily to FX. Now the seasonally higher level of the payroll taxes that occurred in Q1 were fully offset by lower variable compensation in the quarter, which would include both bonus and sales commissions. 
Our marketing expenses decreased by $2.5 million or 8.1%, largely due to a reduction in client events, but also due to the impact of FX. Property, office and technology decreased $1.5 million or 1.4 million, also due to foreign exchange. G&A expenses came in at $44.8 million in the quarter. That was down 2.1 versus the prior quarter. And as again you'll note, the fourth quarter included seasonably higher fund expenses due to year-end mailings in the U.K. and Continental Europe, as well as some professional expenses related to new fund launches.
So despite the net revenue decline of $21.4 million, we were able to mitigate that with very, I’d say, good disciplined expense management. And so our adjusted operating income declined by only $4.9 million to about $183 million. 
One other point is that you'll note that in our non-GAAP presentation, equity and earnings of unconsolidated affiliate no longer reflects our China JV. We now include those revenues and expenses from our JV to our adjusted operating results. And you can see a reconciliation of this in the appendix of the press release.
Below the line in Q1, we did incur a $5 million non-cash charge, and so this -- approximately half of this was due to negative effects on some of our intercompany loans, which was a non-cash impact, and the rest was due to a write-down of a portion of our capital portfolio that was other than temporary impairment. Again, a non-cash impact. 
The effective tax rate increased to 28.7% versus 26.2% in the fourth quarter, largely due to the mix of our assets and revenues. And then so adjusted EPS came in at $0.27 for the quarter, and the adjusted net operating margin came in at 33.6%, slightly above the fourth quarter.
Moving to the next page, just before I turn things over to Marty, I just want to note that we are making some changes going forward to our monthly AUM release beginning with our April release. So we’ll now provide ending AUM without the class decal that's consistent with our earnings presentations. And furthermore, in our effort to align with industry standards and also present our businesses in a more consistent and complete manner, we’ll start including assets for the PowerShares QQQ and the Deutsche Bank, or the DB PowerShares ETF. Currently these assets are not included in our AUM or flows and given the limited definition of AUM that we’d previously used. 
In addition to our normal disclosures going forward, we'll be providing a supplemental schedule that I'll break out ETFs and possibly managed AUM, which will now be counted as part of our total AUM. And so the appendix in today's presentation on Page 37, you'll see that new format for AUM disclosure going forward, as well as a historical representation of the data going back five quarters, and we will provide a quarter-to-quarter average AUM when relevant, and a qualitative statement on any material activity during the month going forward. With that, let me turn it back to Marty, and then we can get to Q&A.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great.  From our point of view, we feel that we are really positioning Invesco for some real good long-term growth and success led by continued strong investment results from our investment teams, continued improvement in net flows as we had highlighted,
componenttext: Great.  From our point of view, we feel that we are really positioning Invesco for some real good long-term growth and success led by continued strong investment results from our investment teams, continued improvement in net flows as we had highlighted, and as Loren just discussed, that strong underwriting operating performance really offset the quarter by some headwinds, foreign exchange in particular. And again, very, very importantly, the Van Kampen Morgan Stanley combination on track to be closed on June 1, and we really think that we’re going to be up and running quite quickly with all the efforts that everybody’s put into it. So we’ll stop there, and Loren and I will answer any questions that anybody might have.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question does come from Dan Fannon of Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question does come from Dan Fannon of Jefferies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, it seems as if we're getting closer to the closing of VanCamp, things are certainly moving in the right direction. Can you give us some background as to what's behind some of the changes, particularly with regards to the outflow assumption or the a
componenttext: Marty, it seems as if we're getting closer to the closing of VanCamp, things are certainly moving in the right direction. Can you give us some background as to what's behind some of the changes, particularly with regards to the outflow assumption or the attrition assumption?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really what it is, is the more -- on the attrition assumption in particular, the more that we understand the business, the more that we've gotten around talking to clients and distributors, we just had a greater confidence in our ability to do that. Do un
componenttext: Really what it is, is the more -- on the attrition assumption in particular, the more that we understand the business, the more that we've gotten around talking to clients and distributors, we just had a greater confidence in our ability to do that. Do understand, it is still an estimate from our point of view, and I think you’re really on the topic. What will likely happen during this, as always, I think we’ve put ourselves in a position to be up and running and as effective as we can, at least from my historical experience, probably been the best that I can associate it with. That said, what's going to happen, as you get to close and then in the next couple of quarters afterwards, on the sales distribution side, it'll probably slow down a little bit because what happens is it’s realignment of the territories for the wholesalers, the big distribution partners are making sure that they go through and do all of their diligence again and make sure that we've not done anything that they’re not happy with and the like. And then it literally starts to pick up probably the second quarter or the third quarter as we start moving forward. But we’re just gaining greater confidence and insight into the combination, a key factor.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the expense side, has anything changed with regards to -- I think your comments originally were that you know investment professionals are going to be impacted more with regards to kind of the back office and whatnot. Can you just give us an update the
componenttext: On the expense side, has anything changed with regards to -- I think your comments originally were that you know investment professionals are going to be impacted more with regards to kind of the back office and whatnot. Can you just give us an update there with regards to the increase in expense synergies and potentially any new areas that you found that potentially are additive?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: What I did say was, yes, the broad categories that we talked about originally have not changed and it is holistically around product lineups and the like, property and the operating platform. So it's really more of the same. And again, it's greater knowledge as we get into it and greater opportunities. So not anything more than that.

componenttext: Our second-year assumption is that the punch ratio goes to about 3.4%. So again, we're in outflows right now. And again, you just look at that relative performance and you go to a normal market, we think a 3.4% punch ratio is very doable.

componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about -- in line with your revised guidance, the timing of the cost saves in year one? Previously, I think it was more back-end loaded. I'm sort of curious with sort of hitting the ground [ph], running on day one, does that change the pace of the saves?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Loren. I think the idea of thinking a little bit more back-end loaded is right. I mean, obviously, it progressively kind of gets factored in. But if you assume that 65% of the savings are in the last six months, and there’s 35% percent in the first
componenttext: It's Loren. I think the idea of thinking a little bit more back-end loaded is right. I mean, obviously, it progressively kind of gets factored in. But if you assume that 65% of the savings are in the last six months, and there’s 35% percent in the first three months, first half of the 12 months after close is probably the right way to think about it.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: For year two, the incremental $10 million or so, would that also be front-end loaded, just given the timing, or more ratable as well?

componenttextpreview: I think that one is more ratable. It's really just the annualization of the benefits in the first 12 months.
componenttext: I think that one is more ratable. It's really just the annualization of the benefits in the first 12 months.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I certainly appreciate the very strong long-term performance, but if you look at some of your sequential changes, I want to talk briefly about March, March-to-March timeframe, do you feel that the short-term performance is a hindrance in any way in terms
componenttext: I certainly appreciate the very strong long-term performance, but if you look at some of your sequential changes, I want to talk briefly about March, March-to-March timeframe, do you feel that the short-term performance is a hindrance in any way in terms of the business? And, well how should we think about trying to balance the short-term versus long-term performance and think about implications from flows?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we, and obviously the investment teams are very cognizant of it. What they've done is a very disciplined, stayed very much on their investment philosophies and process. And when you had that rally -- and some people have referred to it as junk ral
componenttext: I think we, and obviously the investment teams are very cognizant of it. What they've done is a very disciplined, stayed very much on their investment philosophies and process. And when you had that rally -- and some people have referred to it as junk rally at the bottom, we just didn't participate in it. And so not to get too micro, but it's really responsive to your question. If you look at our relative performance in January and February, it's really quite strong. And it was really just this rally that kicked in, in March, and so first part of April, it really has quite an impact on those short-term numbers. That said, you have to look at the strong teams, the strong long-term performance. If we're in a period where you’re going to get another 20% up-market, I suspect the performance would suffer some. It’s just hard to respond to that in a very specific way, other than what I would say is the long-term numbers are strong. Our teams are very consistent with how they’ve been managing the money. And holistically, I think decisions are made on, really, the three-year number is probably the key driver.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned sort of well positioned for this shift to equities, based on your disclosure. Are you seeing in your conversations or your wholesales or institutional sales people, are they seeing any kind of temporal shift in demand for greater equity appe
componenttext: You mentioned sort of well positioned for this shift to equities, based on your disclosure. Are you seeing in your conversations or your wholesales or institutional sales people, are they seeing any kind of temporal shift in demand for greater equity appetite at this point?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say you're not feeling the flows yet. It’s not markedly changed. There’s much greater awareness of the topic on –- you just pick it up everywhere. Is fixed income overvalued at the moment? Is it a more prudent way to move back into equi
componenttext: Yes. I would say you're not feeling the flows yet. It’s not markedly changed. There’s much greater awareness of the topic on –- you just pick it up everywhere. Is fixed income overvalued at the moment? Is it a more prudent way to move back into equities? Yes or no. So you've not seen the dramatic movement, but I'd say very different than maybe a year ago, six months ago. People seem much more inclined to start to pay attention, but you've not seen that dramatic shift yet.

And I think real estate had some alternative capabilities as well. We’re factoring into the numbers.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just more broadly in terms of your thinking about incremental margins. I think, historically, they've been in Canada 60%, 65% range. Does that change following the deal? It seems like maybe you're bringing onboard higher-margin business but at a lower ble
componenttext: Just more broadly in terms of your thinking about incremental margins. I think, historically, they've been in Canada 60%, 65% range. Does that change following the deal? It seems like maybe you're bringing onboard higher-margin business but at a lower blended fee rate. So do those two things effectively offset each other?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's probably the right way to think about it, Michael, that we're pulling the businesses together and are going to be operating in the same way we've operated Invesco traditionally. You're right about the blended rate, but because were being ab
componenttext: I think that's probably the right way to think about it, Michael, that we're pulling the businesses together and are going to be operating in the same way we've operated Invesco traditionally. You're right about the blended rate, but because were being able to leverage our operating platform, we should ultimately be able to provide similar incremental margins. It may be difficult to achieve on day one, but ultimately I think that’s certainly where we would get to.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike Carrier of Deutsche Bank. Your line is open.
componenttext: Mike Carrier of Deutsche Bank. Your line is open.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question I think relates to flows, but really on the distribution side. It seems like with the Morgan Stanley Van Kampen transaction, your strength in the U.S. retail market is significantly expanded. When we look at the different distribution platf
componenttext: First question I think relates to flows, but really on the distribution side. It seems like with the Morgan Stanley Van Kampen transaction, your strength in the U.S. retail market is significantly expanded. When we look at the different distribution platforms, I think when you guys give the organic growth rate or what you think they can do based on performance, that would be roughly in line with the industry. But when you look at it from a distribution standpoint, like as of now, like today where you stand, are you on the platforms across the U.S., and especially the big players? And are you on some of the key distribution lists in terms of partners on those platforms? Just because when you look at the flows on those platforms, it tends to be the top 10 firms are generating 90% of the flows.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. So the combined firm, basically I’m going back to some of -- where Van Kamp and Morgan Stanley had been strong, we had been weak. It's really just almost incredible, the trade-off in the different areas. By the time that we're done, we will be on
componenttext: Right. So the combined firm, basically I’m going back to some of -- where Van Kamp and Morgan Stanley had been strong, we had been weak. It's really just almost incredible, the trade-off in the different areas. By the time that we're done, we will be one of the – and that's the point we were trying to make on Slide 15, which was talking about the distribution, we're going to be a leading partner, really, in most every one of the top distributors in the United States.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the expenses, obviously, the FX impact depressed the expense base sequentially, but it still seems like across really every bucket there was some decrease. I just wanted to make sure there was no noise there. And then when you start looking at 2011, I
componenttext: On the expenses, obviously, the FX impact depressed the expense base sequentially, but it still seems like across really every bucket there was some decrease. I just wanted to make sure there was no noise there. And then when you start looking at 2011, I know it’s a ways away and a lot can change between now and then, but when you look at just the cash flow generation and once you pass the deal and you use the cash, what are the priorities when you look at 5x dividends? Any increased transactions or deals that you think you guys can still bulk up or add into the holes?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well on expenses, other than the impact on FX, in the first quarter it’s pretty straightforward. There wasn't any noise, so to speak. Obviously, you had the seasonal payroll taxes, but as I mentioned, that was offset by lower variable compensation. So i
componenttext: Well on expenses, other than the impact on FX, in the first quarter it’s pretty straightforward. There wasn't any noise, so to speak. Obviously, you had the seasonal payroll taxes, but as I mentioned, that was offset by lower variable compensation. So if there’s anything that was worth noting, those were the two things that were happening in the quarter. The other expenses I think were pretty much in line with where we thought they would be. In terms of cash flows in 2011, our priorities have not changed in terms of using our cash for funding capital needs for the business as the first call. The next would be acquisitions, if they make sense strategically, and if they also have the financial merit that we require. And then we’d be into somewhat increasing dividend and then stock buybacks. The only other thing I would note on top of that we overlay still a strong desire and a continued focus on maintaining a strong financial position on our balance sheet, that there’s value to the organization to have a certain amount of cash sitting on the balance sheet, which would make us less vulnerable if there were disruptions in the market, as we saw, obviously, in 2009 and 2008. So our goal is to certainly run with enough cash, excess cash and that would allow us to have that flexibility and you can say somewhere around $500 million in excess cash above what's needed in the European subgroup. So that would be kind of just a stake put in the ground right now. But I think to the extent that we’re generating a lot of cash flow, which we should, as opposed to steel, and we've got those metrics in place in terms of the cash, we’d probably back into certainly either – you know, whether as an acquisition or stock buybacks. One of the two would be the next logical place where the cash would be used.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know that these two items tend to be very lumpy, and it's very difficult to gauge. But both performance fees, transaction fees are the other revenues. When you look historically, particularly in transaction fees, they bode very low in terms of like a hi
componenttext: I know that these two items tend to be very lumpy, and it's very difficult to gauge. But both performance fees, transaction fees are the other revenues. When you look historically, particularly in transaction fees, they bode very low in terms of like a historical run rate. And performance, because obviously we could try to figure out the performance across the price, had those two, but on the other revenues on those transaction fees, what type of an environment would you expect to get back, given just a normal level?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, you probably would want to have commercial real estate in a somewhat different spot than it is right now. I think there's still, obviously, issues that are being addressed in that market. I think we're hopeful that were going to begin to see so
componenttext: Obviously, you probably would want to have commercial real estate in a somewhat different spot than it is right now. I think there's still, obviously, issues that are being addressed in that market. I think we're hopeful that were going to begin to see some healing there. So the first leg was the residential, and now the commercial. So hopefully within -- again, I'm not an economist. I couldn’t really tell you that. Maybe within a year. Who knows? Right now, when we plan, certainly we continue to plan ourselves, assuming there are no performance fees and no levels of -- minimal levels of transaction fees, and that way, were not fooling ourselves.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Craig Siegenthaler of Credit Suisse.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Marty, can you provide us with an update on how your shares are positioned now, both in the European market in Asia and also in the U.S.? Do you see channel? Maybe provide us a little bit with your near-term outlook here. And also, is there any current product within the Invesco family or Van Kampen, that you think you can leverage ETF platform for?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the U.S. side, we have four products with ETF, or five. You know who are the big ones, the ones that have been around for so long. We are positioned very differently. The strategy of PowerShares is not to try to go compete with the very passive bu
componenttext: Just on the U.S. side, we have four products with ETF, or five. You know who are the big ones, the ones that have been around for so long. We are positioned very differently. The strategy of PowerShares is not to try to go compete with the very passive businesses that had been in place, and our growth has been really complementary to that. We continue to get great interest, and I suspect the momentum will increase in that business for us in the United States. We've launched PowerShares to ETFs into Canada in January, and some very, very strong initial success selling in the Canadian marketplace right now. Europe, we spent probably about two years right now on the continent. And again, we think that we should make some reasonable traction there. We've not done much in Asia. It is an area that we’ve look at, as probably others have, too. But that’s really the landscape for us right now. And I’m sorry, what was the other part of the question?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other part was with your existing product and the consolidation of Van Kampen, do you see any new ways to put product on the ETF platform that you haven’t been doing before?
componenttext: The other part was with your existing product and the consolidation of Van Kampen, do you see any new ways to put product on the ETF platform that you haven’t been doing before?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can't think of anything specifically that way, but what I would say is that, interestingly, the UID expertise there – you know, obviously very different products, but much you can look to, the ETF business, probably birthed [ph] (21:10) the UID busine
componenttext: I can't think of anything specifically that way, but what I would say is that, interestingly, the UID expertise there – you know, obviously very different products, but much you can look to, the ETF business, probably birthed [ph] (21:10) the UID business, so there’s some real strong expertise and we have been having some real deep conversations about how can we do just exactly the question that you've asked. And I don't have a specific answer to it right now, other than I'm sure good opportunities will come from it.

componenttext: On the Invesco side of the business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We saw a real nice improvement and strong flows come in on the fixed income side. It seems to be lagging a little bit some of your peers here. I'm just wondering what's really driving that? Maybe a specific geography or product? And with your expectations
componenttext: We saw a real nice improvement and strong flows come in on the fixed income side. It seems to be lagging a little bit some of your peers here. I'm just wondering what's really driving that? Maybe a specific geography or product? And with your expectations for equity and product to improve, do you expect that momentum to slow a little bit?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's one of the things that’s misunderstood about our fixed income business and how we are participating. The fundamental fact is, if you look where we are strong, it's a big -- liquidity business is big and strong. And also, it's bank loans,
componenttext: I think that's one of the things that’s misunderstood about our fixed income business and how we are participating. The fundamental fact is, if you look where we are strong, it's a big -- liquidity business is big and strong. And also, it's bank loans, CDOs, high-yields. Those are the strengths where we have good teams in the middle of that spectrum and some good performance, largely due to, as I talked earlier, if you look at the results from IVR and their participation, they’re very, very strong teams. But when you look at where all the flows are going, whether it be global fixed income in the retail market or some of the core fixed income mandates, that is just not a territory that has been an area we’ve penetrated on the retail business historically. So that's really what that gap is, and I think that's probably most misunderstood in the market. Institutionally, the global fixed income product is getting some real traction and we have some good core numbers, but again, it’s different that what’s happened on the retail side of the business. So to answer your question, what I really think is going to continue, the fixed income business can be stronger. What we talked about a couple of calls ago was, there's a strong muni capability that we have. We have more of a national muni presence. Van Kampen has a long history of muni bonds, largely state specific, but also the good high yield product, too, which complements ours. So we’re going to be very, very strong in the muni market. So I think if we think we’re going to a rising tax environment, were going to be positioned fairly well there. So I think we'll see some good strong growth in the muni part of the market for us, fixed income, regardless of the movement to equities. But to me, what we're trying to highlight on Page 15, we have a key trend. If you believe that flows into U.S. and international equities at 17% of industry flows is too low, we are going to be a strong beneficiary of this movement away from equities into fixed income, and I don't think we’ll be cannibalized that much on the fixed income side, just because of the way that we are positioned in fixed income.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Marty, were you looking for any ways to upgrade the global fixed income and Aussie investment grade business, given that's one area that you're going to be maybe underweight after the deal closes?
componenttext: And, Marty, were you looking for any ways to upgrade the global fixed income and Aussie investment grade business, given that's one area that you're going to be maybe underweight after the deal closes?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, what I was trying to communicate is I feel very good about the team and their performance.  It’s been in the institutional market. It’s really, literally, trying to get traction in the retail market and it’s really been over the last three years
componenttext: No, what I was trying to communicate is I feel very good about the team and their performance.  It’s been in the institutional market. It’s really, literally, trying to get traction in the retail market and it’s really been over the last three years, with Karen Dunn Kelly running the fixed income business that has become a single platform and it's really working through some legacy performance on the retail side of the business, is why it's our prior teams that we have just not had that traction.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Just coming back to the distribution footprint post-acquisition. Do you have or can you say how many distribution agreements you may have when you hit the ground running where you are going to be selling both Van Kampen and Aim, whereas prior to the acquisition, you only had one or the other on the platform?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't have the specific numbers, but let me try to answer it. Practically what’s going to happen is, as I said it will be – the fact will be, it will probably slow down for a quarter because all of the partners will be doing what they should do
componenttext: Yes. I don't have the specific numbers, but let me try to answer it. Practically what’s going to happen is, as I said it will be – the fact will be, it will probably slow down for a quarter because all of the partners will be doing what they should do, and do due diligence to make sure that they’re understanding exactly what we look like after the transaction. And then going forward from that point, we’ll just continue to pick up. I don't have the specific numbers of the agreement that we have, but what I can tell you is that, like I said earlier, we will be a top partner at the largest distribution -- distributors in the country.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Exactly right. No. That is what’s happening. And what we are doing literally right now, the various distribution salespeople right now are literally going through training. It’s been going on for two weeks and it’ll go on for another two weeks. So our goal is to be as effective as we can as quickly as we can serving our clients.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the synergies, the operating synergies, if you take the numbers that you gave last fall, and now you add as much as $95 million in cost synergies, you get up to a margin of some 50% or more. And I know you probably have to add, at a minimum, the Aim re
componenttext: On the synergies, the operating synergies, if you take the numbers that you gave last fall, and now you add as much as $95 million in cost synergies, you get up to a margin of some 50% or more. And I know you probably have to add, at a minimum, the Aim revenues and costs in to look at that on a combined basis. But I guess the question is, how would you look at the operating margin of those two businesses combined, relative to your company total, because it looks like it could be considerably higher?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Roger, I think we obviously -- it was a similar question about incremental operating margin and they're going to converge to what we’ve done in the past, and I think the answer is yes, that's kind of the definite goal. Clearly, having more Assets under
componenttext: Roger, I think we obviously -- it was a similar question about incremental operating margin and they're going to converge to what we’ve done in the past, and I think the answer is yes, that's kind of the definite goal. Clearly, having more Assets under management allows one to improve one’s margins. And so I think it’s clearly going to help our margin in terms of bringing on the business. So the firm will benefit significantly. I wouldn’t say we’re going to be at a 50% margin, but I do think –- we feel very confident that we can get back to margins that were sort of in the high -- the numbers that you’ve seen historically in 2007 with this acquisition and also with some equity markets behind us.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, performance fees. Long-term track record is great a perpetual. . .  I think you guys failed the benchmark test this quarter. Loren, any idea, based on what’s rolling off in the June quarter from last year, do the odds look good that those perform
componenttext: First, performance fees. Long-term track record is great a perpetual. . .  I think you guys failed the benchmark test this quarter. Loren, any idea, based on what’s rolling off in the June quarter from last year, do the odds look good that those performance fees bounce back this next quarter?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Because there's really two places where we typically have realized performance fees in the year, the first quarter and the fourth quarter. And that's just the way that these contracts have been set up. And just to remind people, it’s really a small
componenttext: No. Because there's really two places where we typically have realized performance fees in the year, the first quarter and the fourth quarter. And that's just the way that these contracts have been set up. And just to remind people, it’s really a small part of the U.K. business. It’s some investment trusts that have these triggers. I ask that very same question all the time, Ken. Are we going to get the performance fees or not. And the reality is, it's very hard to predict as to whether we will or not. I think the idea is that it's within the realm of possibility that we could see it in the fourth quarter, but the fourth quarter still seems pretty far away relative to where we are today. So certainly in the second quarter on the U.K. side we wouldn’t traditionally see any performance fees. The other place where we've been able to generate performance fees on a quarterly basis, second quarter and third quarter, have been in our Quantitative group, Quantitative Equity. Right now I think where they are relative to the benchmark, it's probably not a realistic assumption for us to be looking for. So again, I would say it’s hard for me to guide people on performance fees because it's a tough one to predict. But I'd say where we are right now in the first quarter is probably a reasonable point to think about and we can surely update you if we see any change.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the tax rate, it had a little pop this quarter. Are you accruing anything for the higher tax rate of Van Kampen, or is this really the rate for the core business or the business x Van Kampen for the year based on mix?
componenttext: On the tax rate, it had a little pop this quarter. Are you accruing anything for the higher tax rate of Van Kampen, or is this really the rate for the core business or the business x Van Kampen for the year based on mix?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There’s some impact to the rate due to the integration charges, because it’s obviously a U.S. focused thing and there are some things that we’re going to get the tax benefit for and others not. But the difference is largely due to the mix. If you th
componenttext: There’s some impact to the rate due to the integration charges, because it’s obviously a U.S. focused thing and there are some things that we’re going to get the tax benefit for and others not. But the difference is largely due to the mix. If you think about the U.K., as I mentioned, becoming a smaller part of the overall mix, it has a 28% tax rate relative to some other parts of the U.S., at a higher rate. It's really , I'd say, driven more by the mix of where we’re earning our profits.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On comp. X all the unusual items, even FX, comp was more or less flat. You mentioned that you reduced the variable computation this quarter, and sales were up. How do we think about compensation -- again, X Van Kampen for the rest of the year? Could it ac
componenttext: On comp. X all the unusual items, even FX, comp was more or less flat. You mentioned that you reduced the variable computation this quarter, and sales were up. How do we think about compensation -- again, X Van Kampen for the rest of the year? Could it actually beat our expectations? And I’d love to hone in on the reasons why.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Excluding the impact of FX, there’re really two elements in the first quarter. One was, obviously we had the seasonal payroll taxes, usually $8 million to $10 million. You can look at history, that’s kind of where it’s stayed in the past.  It was of
componenttext: Excluding the impact of FX, there’re really two elements in the first quarter. One was, obviously we had the seasonal payroll taxes, usually $8 million to $10 million. You can look at history, that’s kind of where it’s stayed in the past.  It was offset by lower variable comp, which again was sales commission and bonus. Sales commissions generally move in line with sales, but the reality is, there’s some sales commissions get paid at a higher rate than others and so it's just a little hard to compare quarter-over-quarter. But I'd say a good portion of the variable comp was related to sales commissions relative to the fourth quarter.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sales were up for the quarter. So that’s. . .
componenttext: Sales were up for the quarter. So that’s. . .

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the point is, because sales were up, I’m saying sales commissions can generally move in line with growing sales, but not always, because depending on what gets sold and when, there are different rates on what a salesperson might make, depending
componenttext: I guess the point is, because sales were up, I’m saying sales commissions can generally move in line with growing sales, but not always, because depending on what gets sold and when, there are different rates on what a salesperson might make, depending on what's being sold. An alternative product might pay out at a higher rate than a stable value product, for example. You can’t just look at sales to know if sales commissions are going up or down.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But the conclusion here is the comp was down due to the variable comp -- or comp was flat as variable comp reductions offset – were offset by the payroll tax. But as we look forward, any help? Should we just think it bounces back -- as revenues increase
componenttext: But the conclusion here is the comp was down due to the variable comp -- or comp was flat as variable comp reductions offset – were offset by the payroll tax. But as we look forward, any help? Should we just think it bounces back -- as revenues increase, the comp goes up from here?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There’s two pieces. One, yes to that last point. So as we earn more, obviously, variable compensation comes back and so that will generally move in line as operating income grows. And hopefully, that's where it's going. I think the other bit, as we have
componenttext: There’s two pieces. One, yes to that last point. So as we earn more, obviously, variable compensation comes back and so that will generally move in line as operating income grows. And hopefully, that's where it's going. I think the other bit, as we have done in the past, we do have some degree of merit increase and stocks that are granted, deferred compensation in February, end of February, and so you’ll see a little bit of the full quarter impact into the future quarters relative to the first quarter. So there is some amount of pickup through that bit.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Robert Lee of KBW, your line is open.

componenttext: First question, at the risk of being a little thickheaded. The $0.19 accretion in year two, I'm assuming that's not an additional –- is that an $0.19 on top of the $0.17 in year one or is that just kind of the run rate in year two?

componenttext: So you added them back in?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: A strategic question on the money fund business, which you guys weathered the storms the past couple of years very well and I know it's a key part of your business. But when you look at your kind of institutional focus and you look at a lot of your compet
componenttext: A strategic question on the money fund business, which you guys weathered the storms the past couple of years very well and I know it's a key part of your business. But when you look at your kind of institutional focus and you look at a lot of your competitors and the way their asset bases are four, five times as large, some maybe even more, are you at all concerned that if that business evolves, that, that business is at risk of becoming sub-scale or in some way needs to be scaled up more?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- even with the runoff of – currently, if you look at where it had been historically, you're still at historical levels, right. We were just a big beneficiary of big inflows during the crisis as being one of the managers that was doing a g
componenttext: I think it's -- even with the runoff of – currently, if you look at where it had been historically, you're still at historical levels, right. We were just a big beneficiary of big inflows during the crisis as being one of the managers that was doing a good job. And so it’s a very high-quality team, I would say we’re the industry leading teams, if you just look at what they've done. And it is a part of the whole fixed income complex. So it’s not sitting by itself. So that credit discipline and expertise literally goes across the spectrum. And when we think it’s -- we do it very, very well. We think we have good scale now. I think at the end of the day, quality wins, and I think we’re going to be one of the winners in that business. And, again, it is as complementary to all of our fixed-income capabilities and what we do. As you look at it right now, that asset class is under pressure for all of the obvious reasons. People seeking higher yields, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera. That said, I think we’re going to be fine.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Looking at Morgan Stanley business and on the improvement in their flow trends, can I just get some color on where you see that? headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give us maybe a little bit of additional color on the institutional businesses? I know you talked about fixed income starting to see more traction institutionally. But as we look around the globe, where you're seeing the real opportunity, not ju
componenttext: Could you give us maybe a little bit of additional color on the institutional businesses? I know you talked about fixed income starting to see more traction institutionally. But as we look around the globe, where you're seeing the real opportunity, not just fixed income. Where in the equities or alternatives do you think we should see a continuation of the improving trends over the coming quarters.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: A handful of things. One, I just think what Mark Harmer’s done and the leadership, I think you first start by range of investment disciplines, and they're quite strong -- performing quite strong lately. You match that up against really improving talent
componenttext: A handful of things. One, I just think what Mark Harmer’s done and the leadership, I think you first start by range of investment disciplines, and they're quite strong -- performing quite strong lately. You match that up against really improving talent on the sale-servicing side. I think that’s going to be a very important factor for us going forward. It has also whetted the appetite. So we’re going to continue to see the appetite. Stable value continues to be an appetite, real estate continues to be very, very attractive to people. Bank loans, CLOs, CDOs, those types of banks are very attractive to people. This is the things that were seeing. On the equity side -- Actually Global Fixed Income is another area that we're seeing quite a bit of interest. On the equity side, the Global Equity capability is getting more interest. So it's pretty broad, but again, it's very reflective of what clients are looking for and it's different in different parts of the world. Where if you go to the U.K. and Europe, part of the Quantitative team is based there, so there's a Global Equity Quantitative product that's been doing very, very well in the U.K. So it literally is different region by region. But I would say the trend that we’re on is as strong as it’s been since I've been here.

In addition, words such as believes, expects, anticipates, intends, plans, estimates, projects, forecasts, and future or conditional verbs, such as will, may, could, should, and would, as well as any other statement that necessarily depends on future events, are intended to identify forward-looking statements.
