This presentation and comments made in the associated conference call today may include forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements include information concerning future results of our operations, expenses, earnings, liquidity, cash flow and capital expenditures, industry or market conditions, AUM, acquisitions, debt and our ability to obtain additional financing or make payments, regulatory developments, demand for and pricing of our products and other aspects of our business or general economic conditions. In addition, words such as believe, expects, anticipates, intends, plans, estimates, projects, forecasts and future or conditional verbs, such as will, may, could, should, and would as well as any other statement that necessarily depends on future events are intended to identify forward-looking statements. 
Forward-looking statements are not guarantees, and they involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions. There can be no assurance that actual results will not differ materially from our expectations. We caution investors not to rely unduly on any forward-looking statements and urge you to carefully consider the risks described in our most recent form 10-K and subsequent Forms 10-Q filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
You may obtain these reports from the SEC's website at www.sec.gov. We expressly disclaim any obligation to update the information in any public disclosure, if any forward-looking statement later turns out to be inaccurate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's Second Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Mr. Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. M
componenttext:
Welcome to Invesco's Second Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Mr. Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. 
Mr. Flanagan, you may now begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thank you, everybody for joining us today. And we'll be speaking to the presentation that's available on our website, if you're so inclined to follow. And also, as you know, we've scheduled an Investor Day presentation later this
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thank you, everybody for joining us today. And we'll be speaking to the presentation that's available on our website, if you're so inclined to follow. And also, as you know, we've scheduled an Investor Day presentation later this afternoon, where we're going to much greater detail, regarding the impact of our recent acquisition. But for this call, we'll review the business results, brief update on the combination with Morgan Stanley's retail business, and then Loren will go into financial details, and then as always, we'll go into Q&A.
So those that are so inclined to follow, I'm on Slide 3 right now. In spite of continued volatility in the markets, Invesco's commitment to invest in excellence continue to yield strong long-term investment performance for our clients. Investment performance across the enterprise remain very strong in the second quarter, with some areas that's just exceptional performance. 
Our strong investment performance supported a continued trend of positive long-term net flows for the firm. And as you know on June 1, we completed the acquisition of Morgan Stanley's Retail Asset Management business, which included Van Kampen Investments. This marked a key milestone for our long-term success as a company. 
In one month after the close, we're seeing strong momentum in the combined business. And as we announced last quarter, based on more detailed analysis and understanding of the business, the synergies will be meaningfully stronger than our initial expectations. We'll provide an update on the benefits we're seeing from the acquisition later in this discussion this morning.
So moving now to the second quarter results. Assets under management, end of the quarter at $557 billion under management, and this reflects the combined organization. Adjusted operating income for the second quarter was $188.7 million. That was a 3.1% increase as compared to the first quarter. And long-term net flows for the quarter were $13.9 billion, continuing the positive trend we've demonstrated over the past several quarters. And during the quarter, there'll be a second quarter dividend of $0.11 per share. This is consistent with the first quarter dividend and represents a 7.3% increase over the dividend from the fourth quarter of 2009.  And again, as I've mentioned, Loren's going to go into much greater detail of the financial results in just a minute. 
If you take a look of the quarterly flows starting on Slide  5, what you'll notice, strength in the second quarter gross sales particularly in the passive channel, which led to continued momentum of our long-term flows. And as I mentioned earlier, our long-term net flows for the quarter were $13.9 billion. This represents the sixth consecutive quarter positive flows for Invesco. 
And on Slide 6, you'll note that strong gross sales across the Institutional channel contributed to the positive flows for Invesco, overall, during the quarter.  We also saw so positive flows in our Private Wealth Management business, which has experienced consistent asset growth in each quarter over the past three years. 
And if you take a look at the investment performance, that's one of the key reasons for the enhanced stability of our flows. It's, again, as always, driven by consistent good long-term performance. If you look at the firm as a whole, 75% of the assets under management were ahead of peers on a three-year basis at end of this quarter. This is a significant improvement from 69% of assets ahead of peers on a three-year basis at the end of last year. 
We also saw a strong improvement in performance over the one-year period, now 68% of the assets from the top half of peer group versus 44% in the first quarter. And as always, you'll find the detailed charts in the appendix. But let me take a moment to highlight some of the investment performance across the firm. 
As I mentioned earlier, we saw strong performance across the enterprise, with pockets of exceptional performance. If you start with Invesco Perpetual, they continue to have outstanding performance, with 91% and 95% of their assets under management in the top half of peers over three and five years. With the addition of Van Kampen, the US Value franchise has -- results are stellar performance, with 92% of the assets in the top half of the peer group over three- and five-year period.
Our global fixed income capability continues to achieve strong outstanding performance, with 95% of the assets in the top half of peers on a one year basis and 80% of the asset in the top half over years three and five.  And our Morningstar ratings continue to be near the highest levels since October of the year 2000. So all in all, strong performance across the enterprise.
We'll go into a much greater detail regarding the positive impact of the acquisition on our business at the Investor Day meeting later today, as I mentioned. But for now let's spend a few minutes on a brief update of that business. 
We're pleased to report that businesses were fully integrated with minimal transition issues. More importantly, the work done in the month, leading up to the close, ensured that we are ready to deliver for clients on day one. That was our goal, and that's actually happened. This was also supported by an intensive pre-close training effort for our U.S. sales force so they could engage with clients immediately after the close, to help them understand the added value of the combined organization. And our increased relevance as a top 10 investment manager in this channel is enhancing Invesco's profile in the marketplace in helping gain greater access to top platforms, which, obviously in time, will drive new business. So the work to refine and enhance the product lineup is on schedule.
And as I mentioned, we'll go into much greater detail this afternoon, but some of the points I'd like to highlight: Our focus now is very much on delivering the tremendous value of the combined organization to our clients. The combined investment teams were fully resourced at close to ensure they remain focused on delivering that strong investment performance that they have. And we've organized the combined sales team to provide broad deep coverage in key growth channels and of course to our top clients. And we transitioned clients to the acquired business onto our global operating platform with minimal disruption. And our transfer agency operations begins reporting fund shareholders on first day after close. 
So our goal over the past several months is that to insure we are well positioned to begin delivering the tremendous value of the combined organization to our clients and shareholders and continue the momentum that we have prior to the transaction. So obviously, tremendous work has been done, but most importantly, this is what will drive the momentum of the combined business going forward.
I would like to focus on the next steps remaining until we get to a sort of steady-state operation. We are very focused on sharpening our offering to the clients. Work continues on Phase II, as we are referring to it as, and that's really refining our product lineup. We anticipate this product process, which includes seeking approvals from the fund boards and shareholders will take nine to 12 months after the close. But we are very much on track to accomplish that.
So we're very excited about the combination of the businesses. We see this as a great opportunity to even further enhance our ability to meet our clients' needs. And as always, we're primarily focused on delivering consistent good long-term investment performance to our clients. And the complementary nature of the shared commitment to invest in excellence is very apparent, already within the organization. So we feel very good about the investment teams going forward. 
The acquisition will expand the depth and breath for our investment strategies, providing Invesco with an even greater, more comprehensive range investment capabilities we can offer our clients. And we feel the combined businesses enhances our ability to deliver meaningful solutions to our clients and better position the firm for long-term success.  So with that as a backdrop, I'm going to turn it over to Loren, who'll talk in more depth about the results. And we'll go to questions.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. So going to the next slide, Page 15. You'll see that during the quarter, our net flows provided $13 billion in assets under management.  And the Morgan Stanley, Van Kampen acquisition added $114.6 billion on June 1. These increases in asset
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. So going to the next slide, Page 15. You'll see that during the quarter, our net flows provided $13 billion in assets under management.  And the Morgan Stanley, Van Kampen acquisition added $114.6 billion on June 1. These increases in assets under management were partially offset by a negative market and foreign exchange impacts.
The net increase in AUM was $100 billion, however, quarter-over-quarter. We should point out that the net long-term inflow of $13.9 billion was largely driven by a $15.8 billion lower fee International Equity passive mandate, which was sourced by the Morgan Stanley Japanese team that came over on June 1.  So we ended the quarter with $557.7 billion in assets under management. That's up 21.8% since the end of March. And average AUM for the quarter increased 6.9% to $480.5 billion.
You'll also see at the bottom of the page, our net revenue yield in Q2 increased by 0.6 basis points. And this was primarily a result of strong UIT revenues during the month of June, and also increase in performance fees.
Now let's turn to the next page for the operating results.  You'll see that net revenues increased $44.6 million or 8.2% quarter-over-quarter. The acquired business added $48  million to net revenues for the quarter, but that was offset by $5.5 million from unfavorable foreign exchange rates. 
Drilling a little bit further down on this, you'll see that investment management fees increased by 5.7%, $35.4 million, that was driven by $36.3 million, which was contributed by the acquired business. Service and distribution revenues increased quarter-over-quarter by $26.9 million, about 24%. And again, this is really due to the acquisition, which contributed $25.2 million for the quarter.
Performance fees,  it came in a little higher than the first quarter at $3.5 million. And that was due to fees earned by our real estate group. Other revenues increased by $5.1 million to $16.4 million. And as I mentioned, the acquisition contributed $5.5 million related to new UIT issuance in the month of June. That was very good month for UITs. Third party distribution, service and advisory expense increased by $24.9 million. The acquisition contributed $19 million to the increase. The remainder of that, largely explained by new product launches and somewhat higher average assets under management in Europe.
Moving on down the slide, you'll see that adjusted operating expenses of $400.3 million increased quarter-over-quarter by $38.9  million or 10.8%.  The acquisition added $29.4 million for the quarter, while foreign exchange reduced operating expenses by $2.9 million, when compared to the first quarter. Employee compensation increased by $26 million or 11.1% versus the first quarter. The acquisition added $16.2 million as 580 new staff joined the company on June 1. 
Additionally, the second quarter reflected a full three months worth of expense for share-based, and deferred cash compensation was granted at the end of February of this year. This resulted in the $6 million increase quarter-over-quarter. Furthermore, we recognized about $5 million in severance costs in Q2. And that was related to the reorganization and the continued upgrading of our U.S. institutional sales force.
Marketing expense increased $7.1 million, 25%, that was largely due to the acquired business, which contributed about $6 million of this. Property office and technology increased by 2.3%. Again, largely driven by the new business. The acquired business added $3 million. G&A expenses came in at $48.3 million in the quarter, up $3.5 million. And the acquired business added $4.3 million.
Just going down the page a little bit further, you'll see equity in earnings of unconsolidated affiliates increased by $3.8  million from the first quarter to $4.3 million. This is a result of some gains that were taken in some of our private equity partnership and equity interest. 
For the effective tax rate on pretax adjusted cash net income for the quarter was 29.3% versus 28.7% in the prior quarter. I should note that for the second half of 2010, we expect that our effective tax rate on adjusted basis or comparable basis, that's what I've been talking about, will be about 28%. Although we'll be somewhat lower in Q3 and somewhat higher in Q4 due to the impact of FIN 48. So finishing on this page, we saw that adjusted cash EPS came in $0.27 and the operating margin was 32%.  
Let's just go to the next page and talk a little bit about some more deal metrics. We've updated the deal accretion guidance to $0.22 per share in year one and $0.24 per share in year two. This is due to the net benefit related to the differences in tax amortization of goodwill and definite-lived intangibles versus accounting amortization. The benefit equates about $4 million per year or about $0.01 per share.
We are confirming that we have about a $5 billion expectation of outflow in year one, related to the businesses coming together. And we also believe that the net cost synergy in year one is still around $80 million to $85 million and $90 million to $95 million, year two. I should point out, however, that these cost synergies are net numbers. We have some planned new investments included within these numbers, about $15 million annually, which is an amount largely tied to additional marketing expenses.  And finally on the page, we provide some further detail on our U.S. GAAP intangible amortization for you, those who want to model it. 
Moving to the final slide. I just wanted to provide a reconciliation to you regarding our original set of run rate financials for the acquired business, with the actual results that we've received for one month of earnings disclosed in the press release.  You may remember on September 30 of last year, we provided some high-level information to you that reflected our modeling for the revenues and the expenses of the business that was being carved out and acquired. That time the business had $119 billion in AUM, a run-rate-adjusted operating margin of 32% and a net revenue yield of 40 basis points. Now that's the first column of numbers on the page. 
If you fast-forward nine months later, you'll see that the one month of June actuals annualized shows $114.6 billion of AUM, with an adjusted operating margin of 39% and a net revenue yield of 50.3 basis points. So I wanted to make sure we reconcile these two views for you. 
In September 30 of 2009, run rate P&L, we netted certain operating expenses, specifically related to revenue sharing and fund accounting, against their associated revenues. However, our accounting standards dictate that these expenses in revenues be grossed up for Invesco's income statement and to that added $80 million to revenues and $80 million to expenses, of course with no impact to net income. This does however, have an impact of increase in our net revenue yield of the acquired business by 6.7 basis points.
Next, introducing the net cost synergies in the amount of $80 million to $85 million against the September 30, 2009 P&L. You'll see a view of the business that operates in the adjusted net operating margin of 42% to 43% and a net revenue yield of 46.7 basis points. Comparing this to the annualized one month results, I believe confirms that we're on track to achieve our expected financial results. June seems to be yielding a somewhat higher net revenue yield, about 3.5 basis points, with $20 million more per year. That's a result, we believe, of a very successful month for the UIT business, which generated, as I mentioned about $5.5 million in other revenues, but also a somewhat B share revenue stream that we had originally modeled. 
The annualized June operating expenses are about $30 million greater than what the September 30 P&L after synergies we've forecast. And this difference, however, is in line with our expectations. To state the obvious, there's some noise around one month of data.  So annualizing is tricky, but also, some of the synergies have not been fully realized in the first month of operation.
So overall, I hope this shows you that we're on track period. I should point out, however, that going forward, we're going to be operating this business as one unit. And as a result, we won't be able to provide meaningful or reliable P&L data on Invesco and the Van Kampen, Morgan Stanley business separated from each other. So I am done. And Marty, I'll turn it over to you before Q&A.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Loren. And in closing, as you can sense, yes, we remain very focused on providing strong long-term investments performance for our clients, which has been the contributing factor to continued positive flows within our business. And now,
componenttext: Great. Thank you, Loren. And in closing, as you can sense, yes, we remain very focused on providing strong long-term investments performance for our clients, which has been the contributing factor to continued positive flows within our business. And now, our attention, very much, is on delivering the value of the combined business to our clients. And as Loren noted, we are experiencing strong momentum across the firm. So with that, we'll open it up to Q&A.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question does come from Ken Worthington of JPMC [JPMorgan Chase].

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Your guidance, $80 million to $85 million, of cost synergies, how much of the synergies were actually achieved day one of the deal? Given the margin above, it seems like you've been pretty successful already in generating those synergies.
componenttext: Your guidance, $80 million to $85 million, of cost synergies, how much of the synergies were actually achieved day one of the deal? Given the margin above, it seems like you've been pretty successful already in generating those synergies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, I think we are pretty well there. We didn't obviously -- we weren't able to extract everything. But because we had moved the business over and effectively had all the synergies, most of the synergies baked in from day one, I'd say, we have probably 7
componenttext: Ken, I think we are pretty well there. We didn't obviously -- we weren't able to extract everything. But because we had moved the business over and effectively had all the synergies, most of the synergies baked in from day one, I'd say, we have probably 70% or a little bit higher of the synergy we captured, day one.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Two, you're generating an awful lot of cash flow now that deal's closed. You changed the terms of the deal to include more cash, but your stock price is still low and the valuation is cheap. I assume the priority is still to paydown debt, but would consid
componenttext: Two, you're generating an awful lot of cash flow now that deal's closed. You changed the terms of the deal to include more cash, but your stock price is still low and the valuation is cheap. I assume the priority is still to paydown debt, but would consider purchasing the stock near term based on the valuation and diverting some cash flow there?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Again, I guess, we're always open to looking at the opportunity to deploy our capital to obviously add shareholder value. I think as we've expressed in the past, there is value in our minds to pay down the debt and build up some cash on the balance sheet,
componenttext: Again, I guess, we're always open to looking at the opportunity to deploy our capital to obviously add shareholder value. I think as we've expressed in the past, there is value in our minds to pay down the debt and build up some cash on the balance sheet, just given the uncertainties in markets. And I think everyone sort of seen what volatile markets can do and having some cash on the balance sheet above what we got right now. And certainly, a target of ours, if the stock price were to stay down for some period of time, we certainly, would have that as one of the things we'll be looking at. But our capital priorities are still what they've always been. It haven't changed. And so we also do look at other opportunities to deploy our capital, which will include going around business and also acquisitions.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: There is really two things that drove that. You'll see some of it in the passive category. So there's some commodity products that are ETFs that would show up there. There was about,  I think, $2  billion of outflow or $1.5 billion of currency. It was rea
componenttext: There is really two things that drove that. You'll see some of it in the passive category. So there's some commodity products that are ETFs that would show up there. There was about,  I think, $2  billion of outflow or $1.5 billion of currency. It was really -- I think one of the products was a currency product that's showing up there. I think it was also roughly $1 billion of very low fee European real estate mandate that we deemed in the quarter that really would have very little impact on revenues. It was mostly based on transactional revenues in terms of where the profits were made. And I think that also would account for the both of them.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question does come from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question does come from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010

componenttext: First, now that the deal is done, I think in the past, you've talked about maybe seeing a couple of quarters, where retail flows kind of take a pause as maybe the distributors kind of go through their due diligence and your wholesalers are reorganized. But just given your commentary earlier, do you think you've maybe gotten a bit of a head start on that, and so you might get through that process a bit quicker than expected?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think so is the answer. Now that's said, we are very, very geared up and spending time with the key platforms and distributors and decision-makers to walk them through the transaction. And it's a very serious process, and we're proceeding very wel
componenttext: I don't think so is the answer. Now that's said, we are very, very geared up and spending time with the key platforms and distributors and decision-makers to walk them through the transaction. And it's a very serious process, and we're proceeding very well. We're getting very, very good feedback. But it is going to take its natural course, which is going to be quarter or two. But we're on path to do what we said we did, and the feedback has been positive.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010

componenttext: And then second, can you just give us a little color on the flows in the institutional channel? And then what you're seeing just more recently in terms of activity levels, just given kind of a step up in market volatility?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll make a comment or two, and then Loren can -- we are definitely seeing increased interest in the institutional channel. It's tending to be very much -- real estate is becoming very, very popular again.  That's a big part of the pipeline. There's
componenttext: Maybe I'll make a comment or two, and then Loren can -- we are definitely seeing increased interest in the institutional channel. It's tending to be very much -- real estate is becoming very, very popular again.  That's a big part of the pipeline. There's been  stable value also becoming very interested right now. But then other areas such as bank loans are becoming a Global Equity portfolio. So it's becoming quite broad across the firm in the pipeline, and I think is reflected of, just as you said, plant sponsors starting to get more engaged in the decision-making. Loren?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think obviously, the pipeline is much better than it was a year ago. I think, it's probably significantly better. It is still improving, quarter-over-quarter, I think we're seeing strength 15% plus kind of strength, but really focused on the products th
componenttext: I think obviously, the pipeline is much better than it was a year ago. I think, it's probably significantly better. It is still improving, quarter-over-quarter, I think we're seeing strength 15% plus kind of strength, but really focused on the products that we've talked about in the past, which should be the alternative products, but also barbelled with some of the things like stable value products. So again, I think we're reasonably optimistic for the rest of the year that this is still stabilizing and improving situation and one that we'll benefit from.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010

componenttext: And then finally, I know you reiterated your guidance on kind of the merger-related attrition. But I just wanted to confirm that , I guess, some of the runoff associated with the recent international equity team that I guess got lifted out, that was included in your original guidance, correct?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just make clear about your comment though. What happened, it was a duplicated investment team, and  what we wanted to do was make sure that they had a home. And so we worked with the team to create a home, so very, very constructive. And the reason
componenttext: Let me just make clear about your comment though. What happened, it was a duplicated investment team, and  what we wanted to do was make sure that they had a home. And so we worked with the team to create a home, so very, very constructive. And the reason why we did that was the team was a good team, and we didn't want client disruption. And we thought that it was the exact right thing to do. So there was no lift out or nothing along those lines. So I just wanted to make that point very, very clear.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Roger Freeman of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Roger Freeman of Barclays Capital.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to the $10 billion and sort of this synergy flows you've been talking about, how much of that have you actually gotten notices for already?
componenttext: With respect to the $10 billion and sort of this synergy flows you've been talking about, how much of that have you actually gotten notices for already?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Roger, no. I think that we originally had a $10 billion number just to update you, and then we changed our guidance to $5 billion for the first year after the acquisition. And there's nothing that's been notified. It's really more a forward-looking view,
componenttext: Roger, no. I think that we originally had a $10 billion number just to update you, and then we changed our guidance to $5 billion for the first year after the acquisition. And there's nothing that's been notified. It's really more a forward-looking view, given the fund mergers that we have an expectation will take place as we clean up our product line up. So there isn't a specific account or anything that we can point to as part of that. So again, it has the potential to be better than what the $5 billion is out there. But right now, given the markets, we're still sticking by the $5 billion.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And when it tends to happen would be after the mergers are announced. So I think, between announcement and ultimately the merger date. So that would be fourth quarter this year. First quarter next year would be history of the guidance or when that tends t
componenttext: And when it tends to happen would be after the mergers are announced. So I think, between announcement and ultimately the merger date. So that would be fourth quarter this year. First quarter next year would be history of the guidance or when that tends to happen generally. But again, it will happen as it happens.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And just in the discussions you're having, I guess, on an ongoing basis, with the distributors and them kind of taking a quarter to evaluate the deal. I mean, what are sort of the specifics you're looking for? I would guess, retention of key investment pr
componenttext: And just in the discussions you're having, I guess, on an ongoing basis, with the distributors and them kind of taking a quarter to evaluate the deal. I mean, what are sort of the specifics you're looking for? I would guess, retention of key investment professionals, returns. I mean, you've signed your key folks up for retention packages, and you deliver basically, I guess, it sound s like 70% on sort of the synergies, but are pretty stable. I mean, what are they? I guess, what are the key points they're holding back on?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So what are the communications with the distributors? It's an overview of the combined organization, the depth and breadth of the investment capabilities, depth and breadth of the investment management teams, performance, all of the factors that are norma
componenttext: So what are the communications with the distributors? It's an overview of the combined organization, the depth and breadth of the investment capabilities, depth and breadth of the investment management teams, performance, all of the factors that are normal, along with communication of our abilities to meet our goals within their channels and the broader, deeper sales and support team is very, very important to them. So it's gone very, very well. So it is again, the distributors, as you would, they're very talented, they're very thoughtful, and they have a rigorous process that they would take any firm. So it's going extremely well, and again, they're the client and they're driving the bus. And so they'll determine that timeframe. But it's gone very, very well.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael Carrier at Deutsche Bank, your line is open.
componenttext: Michael Carrier at Deutsche Bank, your line is open.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Quick question on, when I look at the Retail part of the business and mostly with Van Kampen now, and you guys did a good job on the expense side and the revenue side, trying to break out the Legacy business versus the new Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen. I gue
componenttext: Quick question on, when I look at the Retail part of the business and mostly with Van Kampen now, and you guys did a good job on the expense side and the revenue side, trying to break out the Legacy business versus the new Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen. I guess, when you look on the flow side, in particular, as it relates to the Retail business, you've obviously, seen a pickup on the redemption side and sales in the industry just had been pretty sluggish. So I guess, it's going to be hard to do this, but just in the quarter, can you kind of strip out what's related, what you see as more noise versus core and imply more importantly, when you do look over the next quarter, two quarters, three quarters, when do you expect some of the noise to start muting out and being able to take advantage of -- you have the products, your performance is solid and then you're able to take advantage of the distribution opportunity?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me make a couple of broad comments. It's hard to answer specifically, but let me just -- typically what happens. By June 30, there was very little impact of so-called the strength of the combined firm, it's just not practically going to happen, and as
componenttext: Let me make a couple of broad comments. It's hard to answer specifically, but let me just -- typically what happens. By June 30, there was very little impact of so-called the strength of the combined firm, it's just not practically going to happen, and as various talk, previously, now you go through a diligence process and the like. It will literally take, in my mind, two to three quarters by the time you communicate the depth and breadth of the firm, all the way down through the adviser channel. That's just how long it takes. It's tens of thousands of advisers that you need to get in front of and discuss why they're better off the depth and breadth of the firm. The noise, as you talk about it, the fund close stuff, we were trying to put a date out there. So as soon as the fund mergers are done, which we expect to be nine to 12 months after the close, that will be the noisiest period taken out of the system. And the reason why we say nine to 12 months, there's a shareholder vote, we can't control that. So we are very much on track at everything we control, and so it's just an ongoing process. But what you're seeing right now, again, it's very hard to separate market sentiment from parsing sort of a normal course. If you talk to advisers literally from that May period, it wasn't such a redemption topic that drove outflows. It was sales just dropped like a rock, people just froze. So that is really what you're seeing. Now it's really the normal process of people coming back through difficult markets determining when are they going to get back engage and take some exposures to the equity market. So you have two very strong factors happening at the moment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Loren, just on the expenses, if we just take the one month for Van Kampen, and we can quarterly-rize that or whatever you want to say it. But if you look at that $400 million and do that, there were a few items like on the severance in comp that
componenttext: And then Loren, just on the expenses, if we just take the one month for Van Kampen, and we can quarterly-rize that or whatever you want to say it. But if you look at that $400 million and do that, there were a few items like on the severance in comp that you mentioned, I just want to make sure like going forward, any other items that you felt like stood out in the quarter that wouldn't be core? Or is this a pretty good run rate x that severance number?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a pretty good run rate, obviously. As you said multiply the one month by three. So there's seasonality obviously, that occurs first quarter in those types of things that we always talk about, but there's nothing exceptional that we haven't ca
componenttext: I think it's a pretty good run rate, obviously. As you said multiply the one month by three. So there's seasonality obviously, that occurs first quarter in those types of things that we always talk about, but there's nothing exceptional that we haven't called out and that I think I need to bring to your attention.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question does come from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question does come from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the $5 billion forecasted net flow to synergy again, can you talk at all about the expected geography for the planned redemptions, and also timing? So really which channels could be impacted, which products? And maybe, should we think about this b
componenttext: Just on the $5 billion forecasted net flow to synergy again, can you talk at all about the expected geography for the planned redemptions, and also timing? So really which channels could be impacted, which products? And maybe, should we think about this being more front end loaded over the next 12 months rather than back end loaded?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig, it's again, very hard to do it at that level. Right now, we're in the typical process of fund analysis, and again, we have to go through the fund boards to get their support and approval and open to shareholders. But the work that is done is b
componenttext: Yes, Craig, it's again, very hard to do it at that level. Right now, we're in the typical process of fund analysis, and again, we have to go through the fund boards to get their support and approval and open to shareholders. But the work that is done is based on some real experience that we have. So we're just not pulling something out of the air. But the channel that it comes from is largely the retail channel. It is mutual funds and the vast majority of it are typical adviser-sold channel products. So that's where you're going to see it. And as I was mentioning, if history has a guide again after you announced the mergers, which would be probably into maybe the fourth quarter from that period, almost till closing is when you seek redemptions, and that's why I was saying that largely, I think, you'll see them fourth quarter, first quarter next  year will be the timing of it. And I don't have -- I wish I could tell you how much won and what day, but I just don't know.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on the performance fees, the U.K. Perpetual business' performance has really ticked up the last few months here. And also, it looks like I guess, some realized gains on the Wilbur Ross business. Can you talk about if there's any ability to r
componenttext: And then just on the performance fees, the U.K. Perpetual business' performance has really ticked up the last few months here. And also, it looks like I guess, some realized gains on the Wilbur Ross business. Can you talk about if there's any ability to really improve this performance fee level meaningfully in the back half of the year, with those drivers? But also Invesco used to have over $50 million of performance fees a year. When can we go back towards that level too?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, the performance fees in the fourth quarter have been largely focused on the U.K. products. And so the answer, we really have to do with what the one year numbers look like for the  U.K. at that point in time. Obviously, the three and five num
componenttext: Well, again, the performance fees in the fourth quarter have been largely focused on the U.K. products. And so the answer, we really have to do with what the one year numbers look like for the  U.K. at that point in time. Obviously, the three and five numbers are quite strong. Again, sort of a performance based and is there a chance that we could see some performance fees? Yes, I mean, there is. But again, I think the general guidance that we've provided right now is it's probably, there would be a bit of a bet that we're going to get there in time to realize that performance fee. Longer-term, absolutely, we could see those things come back. But certainly, sort of near-term was not in our planning right now, that we're going to see a large performance in the fourth quarter from the U.K. even though, I grant you, their near term performance has really come back very strongly. Beyond that, there aren't that many assets that have performance fees. So the emerging class of products that would have performance fees would be some of the Wilbur Ross products, because they have some carry associated with them. And again, in terms of the carry that we would get, it would be on the newer funds or the funds that were launched after October of 2006. That's the really Fund IV and then any future funds. And we're not quite at the point where we're, I think, seeing realizations on those particular products. The gains that we took weren't related to those products, they're related to other global products. And so again, I just want to make sure you don't assume that we're starting to see a lot of carry coming through in some of those products yet. It's too soon. So again, we do think that some of the performance fees you may have seen in the past also came from our quantitative group, and so there's a potential there that we could see those come back. But right now, given where the performance is, it's not part of our planning that we're going to see that come back this year. So again, hopefully, that helps you again sort of give you a sense of where they can come from.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill Katz of Citigroup.
componenttext: Bill Katz of Citigroup.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to come back to slide 18, if we could for a moment. Loren, you mentioned before that there was some noise in some of the annualized numbers. Can you sort of highlight exactly what those are? And then, am I correct in that, based on the answe
componenttext: I just wanted to come back to slide 18, if we could for a moment. Loren, you mentioned before that there was some noise in some of the annualized numbers. Can you sort of highlight exactly what those are? And then, am I correct in that, based on the answer to a prior question, you still have about 30% of the $80 million to $85 million of annualized saves to be realized? I'm still trying to reconcile the fact that your operating profits are $9 million to $14 million under water relative to the September '09 run rate against your thoughts that you're running ahead of plan.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So again, in terms of the one-month numbers for Van Kampen, I guess the point that I was saying was more of a conceptual one about noise. I mean, I think we're not at the point where we can go and drill down on a month's worth of expenses and say, what's
componenttext: So again, in terms of the one-month numbers for Van Kampen, I guess the point that I was saying was more of a conceptual one about noise. I mean, I think we're not at the point where we can go and drill down on a month's worth of expenses and say, what's unusual based on travel patterns or other things? I'm just saying that I think, take these things with a grain of salt. It's just sort of informative as opposed to a detailed reconciliation. In terms of kind of where the synergies are, again, the fact that we're saying that we've achieved sort of 70% of run rate on the synergies day one, I think, is probably good in terms of where we want it to be. We hope to get the rest through the course of the year. And again, so I think that means, in my mind, that we're on track and obviously, we just brought the business over so we have a little time to move and get the rest of the synergies. So I guess in terms of your last point, Bill, I'm not sure if you're saying that you think we're not on track or...

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010

componenttext: Well, it's just the way the slide reads. It's $9 million to $14 million variance relative to the initial run rate. I was just trying to box that against the incremental savings still to be had.

componenttext: Yes. And again, it's just one month of data. So again, I view that as close enough in terms of where we expected it to be, just to give the people a sense that we're on track.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question is just in terms of Wilbur Ross. I think there's been sort of some expectation that he might close to raising his fifth recovery fund. Just wondering if you could update us where we stand on Wilbur Ross IV [WLR Fund IV] perhaps, WLR IV
componenttext: The second question is just in terms of Wilbur Ross. I think there's been sort of some expectation that he might close to raising his fifth recovery fund. Just wondering if you could update us where we stand on Wilbur Ross IV [WLR Fund IV] perhaps, WLR IV, and maybe the timing for a potential new raise?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of Fund IV, think we are sort of not quite at the full 75%. But we have a pipeline of investments that eventually, I think, will clearly get us over the 75%, which would allow for future fund raise that's in terms of Fund V, again, we're no
componenttext: Well, in terms of Fund IV, think we are sort of not quite at the full 75%. But we have a pipeline of investments that eventually, I think, will clearly get us over the 75%, which would allow for future fund raise that's in terms of Fund V, again, we're not at this point able to talk about this fund launch, given that private placement rules. So we really would not want to be commenting about size or anything of that nature.

componenttext: I apologize if you covered this already, but if you look at Page 6, the Institutional flows dropped pretty precipitously if you back out the large passive mandate. componenttext: So in terms of the decline in the Institutional mandates, I think we've mentioned one at least that there was a very low fee, real estate mandate. There was about $1 billion that last, it was virtually no fee. And so in any event, that was one part of it. Other parts, I think it's a variety of smaller mandates, so there's really nothing I can point to explicitly. The real estate one was by far, the biggest element. In terms of the Institutional mandate that came over, we don't talk about specific fee relationships on new single mandates, other than sort of the guiding, so we said it's sort of a low fee mandate. But again, it's one that we we're pleased to obviously, have severance fees as part of the skew.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And just on that mandate, was that gotten at sort of an ordinary RFP process? Or is it really more a sort of an acquired asset?
componenttext: And just on that mandate, was that gotten at sort of an ordinary RFP process? Or is it really more a sort of an acquired asset?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it was not acquired in the sense that we certainly, had no intention of buying it. It came over really based on the strength of the relationship of the Japanese team with the client. It was previously served by Morgan Stanley, and so it came over to
componenttext: Well, it was not acquired in the sense that we certainly, had no intention of buying it. It came over really based on the strength of the relationship of the Japanese team with the client. It was previously served by Morgan Stanley, and so it came over to us based on that. And I wouldn't call it necessarily an RFP, but there's certainly, a diligence process that took place.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe if you could just sort of give us your outlook on the money market business and how you see fee waivers from here and close.
componenttext: Maybe if you could just sort of give us your outlook on the money market business and how you see fee waivers from here and close.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: For us, Cynthia, we don't have fee waivers just because of the pricing of our products. So that's unfortunate for us as an organization. Just from the asset class generally, we're still strong believers there's a very good strong vehicle, serves a real pu
componenttext: For us, Cynthia, we don't have fee waivers just because of the pricing of our products. So that's unfortunate for us as an organization. Just from the asset class generally, we're still strong believers there's a very good strong vehicle, serves a real purpose, and I think, just looking at the level of assets in the Money Fund business with the current rate structures would conclude something it is very positive there. And I think, there is the outlook for growth is going to largely be driven by change in the interest rate environment. And I don't think any of us are counting on that at the moment. I think structurally, there is a round of changes that went through the industry. We all think they're very, very positive. There's continued discussion of what is are all the changes that need to be made, have they been made in that dialogue has continued to be open. But in total, we think it's a very good asset class. But don't expect it to be growing until the interest rate environment should.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I guess, quarter-to-quarter, there's such a variety of things between tax payments and other things. I mean, it's sort of an annualized view when we look out with the full year behind us, we think that $900 billion of free cash flow generatio
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I guess, quarter-to-quarter, there's such a variety of things between tax payments and other things. I mean, it's sort of an annualized view when we look out with the full year behind us, we think that $900 billion of free cash flow generation is the number that we get when we do the modeling. That assumes kind of normal equity markets and some general continuation of positive investment performance and so forth.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on a leverage basis or if you can think about your debt levels, what would you like to get back to? Where do you feel most comfortable at with that kind of backdrop?
componenttext: And then on a leverage basis or if you can think about your debt levels, what would you like to get back to? Where do you feel most comfortable at with that kind of backdrop?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our expectation is that we paid down the credit facility. Right now we have about $650 million that's borrowed against that, and that would be kind of one element in terms of debt reduction. Beyond that, we have no stated plans or further kind of th
componenttext: Well, our expectation is that we paid down the credit facility. Right now we have about $650 million that's borrowed against that, and that would be kind of one element in terms of debt reduction. Beyond that, we have no stated plans or further kind of thinking about further reducing debt or adding debt for that matter. We feel comfortable with our situation right now. We have expressed certainly, some desire to raise some more cash. We'd like to have somewhere around $800 million to $1 billion of cash on the balance sheet. Just generally, we think that, that's prudent to have a reserve when needed, and not be reliant on capital markets when we need cash.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then switching to the UIT products, can you help us understand a little bit about the fees associated with that, and what your outlook is for growing that product? It seems you had a good month in June, is that one off in nature? Or how are you thinki
componenttext: And then switching to the UIT products, can you help us understand a little bit about the fees associated with that, and what your outlook is for growing that product? It seems you had a good month in June, is that one off in nature? Or how are you thinking about that product going forward?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, $5.5 million which we associated with the UIT business in the month is I think a reasonably high number in the sense that historically, it's probably, it's higher than the norms. If you were to look going forward, would it be more $5 million
componenttext: Well, again, $5.5 million which we associated with the UIT business in the month is I think a reasonably high number in the sense that historically, it's probably, it's higher than the norms. If you were to look going forward, would it be more $5 million or $4.5 million, somewhere in that range probably if you were to ask UIT folks, that they would say is a normal sort of run rate for them. Again, the way it works, it's a little complicated because there are different fees and revenues based on what type of UITs you're generating with it, there's fixed income or equity. So again, it would probably take more time than you probably want, and I have to go through exactly how it works. But the revenues have generated upfront upon the sale, so they're not really based on ongoing management fees, and the margins are very healthy with that business. It's a very profitable business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Lee of KBW.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, first one, just the severance in comp. You mentioned that was related to the continuing kind of reshaping of your distribution platform. I'm assuming you meant institutional platform, and are we pretty much at the end of that? You t
componenttext: A couple of questions, first one, just the severance in comp. You mentioned that was related to the continuing kind of reshaping of your distribution platform. I'm assuming you meant institutional platform, and are we pretty much at the end of that? You think you have that where you need to be? Or can we expect a little bit more of that going forward?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010

componenttext: Robert, I think where the bulk of it took place this quarter, I think, there's still some more work that's anticipated. But I think, right now, the majority of some costs associated with it I think has been realized this quarter. It's been an ongoing process. It didn't really happen just this quarter. I think it's been a process that's been going on for several quarters, and it's one that we feel really good about in terms of the benefits it'll bring to the firm.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe shifting gears a bit to the ETF business. I gather this quarter had some outflows, but can you maybe talk more broadly about that business? It only seems like competitors are kind of popping out of the woodwork everyday. And do you look forward?
componenttext: And maybe shifting gears a bit to the ETF business. I gather this quarter had some outflows, but can you maybe talk more broadly about that business? It only seems like competitors are kind of popping out of the woodwork everyday. And do you look forward? Where do you really see some of the opportunity for you to kind of differentiate yourself? Is it kind of doing more kind of, I guess I'll call it white label type products? I'm just trying to get a sense for where you kind of see yourself differentiating from the increasingly crowded field out there.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Needless to say, we're still very positive on the ETF business, stating the obvious, right. It's a growing business. It's finding its place in the marketplace with advisers, in addition to portfolio managers and the like. So our place has not changed, rig
componenttext: Needless to say, we're still very positive on the ETF business, stating the obvious, right. It's a growing business. It's finding its place in the marketplace with advisers, in addition to portfolio managers and the like. So our place has not changed, right. We are not trying to be sort of me-too passive ETF provider. That space has been taken. The whole PowerShares philosophy has been one of really creating -- and again everything is an index. But again, you could create these indexes around investment processes and the like. And so it's really the value-added ETFs, and we think that's going to continue to be a growing part of the business. We're very committed to it. And from a strategic point of view though, many, many people are trying to get into the business. I think differently than mutual fund where you can have, pick a number, 200 of the same mandate mutual fund. That really is not possible with ETFs, because you need a market maker and capital has to go bought. So you really can have maybe a couple three, possibly four light-designed ETF. So I think there is limited shelf space ultimately. I think that's one of the other attractive things to that business. But we're very pleased with where we are with the ETF business. And we're getting more and more traction. We've had some early success in Canada. We see other parts of the world where we will continue to make an impact.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: There's been, I guess, some price competition and more on the kind of plain vanilla size of business. I mean, do you see that kind of creeping in to the segments that you compete in?
componenttext: There's been, I guess, some price competition and more on the kind of plain vanilla size of business. I mean, do you see that kind of creeping in to the segments that you compete in?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Less so, I mean, for obvious reasons. I mean, I think, it's just very typical whether you sort of ignore the structure, whether there's ETF or the institutional separate account or the like, where you'd get the greatest fee pressure. It tends to be in the
componenttext: Less so, I mean, for obvious reasons. I mean, I think, it's just very typical whether you sort of ignore the structure, whether there's ETF or the institutional separate account or the like, where you'd get the greatest fee pressure. It tends to be in the areas that tend to be the passive type mandates. So the more value you offer, the higher fee you can justify. And that's been the case so far.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Probably in that [indiscernible] chance to go through it, but your initial thoughts on the 12b-1 fee proposals relatively benign for the fund industry. Do you think that there's big impact on way or the other? I mean, what's your kind of initial take?
componenttext: Probably in that [indiscernible] chance to go through it, but your initial thoughts on the 12b-1 fee proposals relatively benign for the fund industry. Do you think that there's big impact on way or the other? I mean, what's your kind of initial take?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, yes, it's been ongoing dialogue with regulators for the last number of years. And I think what was proposed is really no surprise to the industry. It's very much along the lines of what the SEC was working on. There are some elements that are pos
componenttext: I think, yes, it's been ongoing dialogue with regulators for the last number of years. And I think what was proposed is really no surprise to the industry. It's very much along the lines of what the SEC was working on. There are some elements that are positive, I think, and that we are just naming conventions, and then also, getting the directors out of a process to approve something, which was a very difficult thing to do. And I think if you look at where the bulk of the industry sales have gone, with the 25 basis point service fee, I don't think you're going to see a tremendous impact. There are some real operational challenges, I think, you're going to see coming out of the coming period. I just don't know that what's being suggested can be done on any short period of time. So that's one topic. But it will be interesting to see what happens to the coming period. But I don't see a tremendous shock to the system with this. I think, it's pretty consistent with what people have been thinking.

componenttext: Mark, I think, it should be largely neutral. And once we get those understood, I'd be able to answer more fully. Obviously, it's not our expectation that it's going to be fairly benign in terms of how the two fund ranges come together from a fee perspective, and obviously, positive ultimately for flows and certainly other expense ratios.

componenttext: Marty, just a question for you on U.S. versus non-U.S. retail investor behavior. Can you just comment a little bit on what you saw in the past quarter? And is there something worth noting overseas versus the U.S. in terms of what you're seeing from retail investors?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it was a pretty similar experience, the feedback we had in different parts of the world too. I mean, people were -- and maybe a little more in the United States, I think, you have a combination of states, we're going to call it "the Greek deb
componenttext: Yes, I think it was a pretty similar experience, the feedback we had in different parts of the world too. I mean, people were -- and maybe a little more in the United States, I think, you have a combination of states, we're going to call it "the Greek debt crisis", along with the flash crash. It really sort of struck investors in talking to different advisers and their volume just dropped dramatically. And as I mentioned earlier, it wasn't so much of a redemption thing. It was this stopping of sales or investments. So it's probably a little more difficult here, but you did see a slowdown in other retail markets. And again, I'd still say investor confidence in the individual level is still wanting to take a greater exposure. But very, very fickle and nervous at the moment.

Forward-looking statements include information concerning future results of our operations, expenses, earnings, liquidity, cash flow and capital expenditures, industry or market conditions, AUM, acquisitions, debt and our ability to obtain additional financing or make payments, regulatory developments, demand for and pricing of our products, and other aspects of our business or general economic conditions.
