componenttext: This presentation and comments made in the associated conference call today may include forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements include information concerning future results of our operations, expenses, earnings, liquidity, cash flow and capital expenditures, industry or market conditions, AUM, acquisitions, debt and our ability to obtain additional financing or make payments, regulatory developments, demand for and pricing of our products and other aspects of our business or general economic conditions. In addition, words such as believe, expects, anticipates, intends, plans, estimates, projects, forecasts and future or conditional verbs, such as will, may, could, should, and would as well as any other statement that necessarily depends on future events are intended to identify forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are not guarantees, and they involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions. There can be no assurance that actual results will not differ materially from our expectations. We caution investors not to rely unduly on any forward-looking statements and urge you to carefully consider the risks described in our most recent form 10-K and subsequent Forms 10-Q filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. You may obtain these reports from the SEC's website at www.sec.gov. We expressly disclaim any obligation to update the information in any public disclosure, if any forward-looking statement later turns out to be inaccurate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's Third Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to the speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Mr. Lawrence R., Chief Financial Officer. Mr. F
componenttext: Welcome to Invesco's Third Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Now I would like to turn the call over to the speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Mr. Lawrence R., Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Flanagan, you may now begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you, everybody, for joining us, and this is Martin Flanagan, and along with Loren Starr, as was just pointed out. Loren and I will be speaking to the presentation that's available on the website, if you're so inclined to follow alo
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you, everybody, for joining us, and this is Martin Flanagan, and along with Loren Starr, as was just pointed out. Loren and I will be speaking to the presentation that's available on the website, if you're so inclined to follow along. What we'll do today is, I'll highlight the business results, and we'll spend a few minutes just on the current update of the combination with Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen, the combination that we just closed in June. And then Loren will go into greater detail on the financials. And then finally, we'll open up to Q&A.
And so those that are inclined to follow, I'm going to start on Page 2 of the presentation today. So if you look at the quarters, in spite of the continued volatility that we saw in the markets, Invesco's commitment to investment excellence really did yield a strong quarter, with continued strong investment performance across the enterprise. It remained very strong and with some areas of obviously the exceptional performance. The strong investment performance contributed to a continued trend of our long term inflows into the organization. And as many of you know, not all of you -- on June 1, we completed the combination with Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen Retail Asset Management business. And our goal from the day we announced the transaction was to complete the integration work prior to the close and thanks to tremendous amount of effort on everybody's part, we accomplished that goal and we're able to deliver the value of the combined firm on day one as we referred to it. And now since we've completed it, we've now had a full quarter of the combined organization together in received strong momentum of that combined business. 
I'd also like to mention, during this third quarter, we resumed our share repurchase program and purchased 6.4 million shares, with the value of about $127 million. Later in this presentation, Lawrence is going to give some insight into our capital management approach. And also, I'd like to note that Standard & Poor's increased our enterprise risk management rating from adequate to strong. Invesco is now one of the four strong for asset managers with a strong rating.
So if you take a look at Slide 3, assets under management ended the quarter at $604 billion and that compares to $557 billion at the end of the second quarter, reflecting the improved markets and also strong momentum in our combined business. Adjusted operating income for the third quarter was $245 million, an increase of 30% quarter-over-quarter, and long-term net inflows for the quarter were $4.9 billion, continued the positive trend we've demonstrated over the past several quarters. And consistent with the second quarter, we will provide a third quarter dividend of $0.11 per share. And again, Loren will go into much greater detail of the financials in just a moment.
If you take a look at the quarterly flows on Page 4, you'll see the strength in the third quarter gross sales lead to continued positive momentum in our long-term net inflows. And as I mentioned earlier, the long-term net inflows for the quarter were corporate $4.9 billion. This represents a seven consecutive quarter of positive inflows for Invesco. 
And if you take a look on Slide 5 at the gross sales across retail and institutional channels, we continued to contribute positive net flows to Invesco, overall. And also, if you look at the Private Wealth Management segment of the business, it continued to experience consistent asset growth quarter-over-quarter. And we've seen net inflows for the past three years in the Private Wealth Management business. And if you take a look at investment performance for the group, it's one of the key reasons for the enhanced strength and stability of close that we've seen over the past seven quarters. And if you look at the enterprise, 78% of the assets were ahead of peers on a three-year basis. And that compares to 71% one year ago, so continued improvement and strength and consistent good long-term performance. And again, the detailed charts of performance are in the appendix that you're so inclined. I would like to take a minute just to highlight some of the pockets of exceptional performance.
And starting with the long-term investment performance that Invesco Perpetual remains just outstanding, with more than 90% of the assets from the top half of peers over one, three and five years. We continue to see improvement in Invesco Trimark with 81% of the Canadian equity assets from the top half of the peer groups on a three-year basis from 65% on a one-year basis. Our global fixed income capability continues to achieve outstanding performance with 90% of the assets from the top half of peers on a one year basis, and 86% of assets from the top half of five years. Invesco Real Estate maintained a strong competitive position with 99% above the benchmark for three years, and 92% of the benchmark across five years, really just outstanding performance. And Morningstar ratings in the U.S. Retail business remain near the highest levels since October 2000 with 58% of the U.S. retail assets rated four or five stars.
So, I'd like to take a few minutes and just brief everybody on the momentum we're seeing in the combined business. And on Page 9, just a couple of the highlights, as I mentioned, we're very pleased to report that we are fully integrated with minimal transaction issues. And from that period, it's been really supported by an intensive pre-close training effort, which we discussed previously. Now retail sales force has been actively engaged with clients, and we're seeing steadily increasing momentum in that business. Our relevance as a top 10 U.S. fund manager is really enhancing Invesco's profile in the marketplace, and it's helping us gain greater access to top platforms in driving new business. And the Phase II work of rationalizing our product lineup is on schedule.
As if you take a look at Page 10, at the time of close last quarter, we told you what we had accomplished at the close. And it would not have happened without just tremendous amount of effort on both sides, both Invesco and Morgan Stanley. And that was an important milestone. But really, let's spend a minute on what the progress since the close and we've made steady progress building the Commodity business across three broad areas: clients, operational excellence and employee engagement. And most notably, U.S. retail asset close were on target and growing. We continue to enhance our profile on key platforms. We're actively engaged in clients with business plans for each client and deeper coverage teams aligned against them. Our product realignment efforts are on track, and we achieved our expense targets that we laid out at the beginning of the combination. Loren will discuss that more. And most importantly, we have a strong, engaged, stable investment management team in place, producing strong results for our clients. 
So if you take a look at Page 11, and give this greater focus in your minds, we've highlighted from the initial announcement of the combination with Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen, it was highly complimentary to Invesco's existing capabilities. And if you look at the two organizations, pre-close, you can get a sense of the product mix, and we know how was -- Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen was very complimentary and specialized fixed income and equity, but you can see the vehicle mix here, and post the close, you can look at the long term business in the United States as ETFs. UIT has been 31%; mutual funds, 44%; NBC and insurance, 25%. And the point is, in a really challenging U.S. equity mutual funds environment, the diversity provides real balance and clear benefits, not just for the clients, but also for the business. 
And if you look on Page 12, you can see what's happened. Post to close, we've continued to see solid momentum in this U.S. Retail business. Yes, driven by the strong investment performance, the client focus and the engagement, but what you'll note is, the incremental impact of the combined organization is clearly positive. And so if you look month-over-month, pre-close and post close, what you'll note is the trend, month over month of increased gross sales, and you'll see that post close, the punchline is this, average monthly gross sales are up 40%, and the average monthly redemption rate has declined 12 percentage points, which is really quite amazing. And I think you have to put it in the context so the flash crash in May, which is was very pronounced here in the United States. So that would be the early results of the combination. I'd still say we're very early in what we expect out of the combination as we look forward. 
The other thing that we've seen is, we continue to expand our presence on key client my platforms. There has been a 240% increase for the platform placements since the month of June, so that number of funds being put in a preferred rating with the different platforms. And again, we just continue to see growing interest in activity with the business. So our view is, that right now, we are on track, very, very much on track. And we think more good things to come. Just to bring you up to speed on where we are on Slide 13, really, the Phase II of the integration, it's really just a very, very sharp focus on the product offering for our clients. We anticipate this process to be done six to nine months after the September 30 close. We are well into the effort of seeking approval from the fund boards and ultimately from shareholders. But that process is on track and moving forward. So I'm going to stop there and hand it over to Loren.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, very much, Marty. Basically, during the quarter, our net long term flows provided $4.9 billion in AUM. Market gains provided $34.4 billion, FX added $8.2 billion and then acquisitions, net of this dispositions added $1.7  billion. These increases
componenttext:
Thanks, very much, Marty. Basically, during the quarter, our net long term flows provided $4.9 billion in AUM. Market gains provided $34.4 billion, FX added $8.2 billion and then acquisitions, net of this dispositions added $1.7  billion. These increases in AUM were partially offset by net outflows from money market funds of $2.4 billion. But the increase in AUM quarter-over-quarter was $46.8 billion or 8.4%, resulting in the ending assets of $604.5 billion. Our average assets under management actually increased more strongly, 21.4% to $583.3 billion. And this was primarily due to three full months of the Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen Asset Management business in Q3 as opposed to only one month in Q2. Our net revenue yield in Q3 was 48.5 basis points, down only slightly quarter-over-quarter. And now let me turn to the operating results.
That quarter-over-quarter variances in P&L that you're going to see are largely due to the two additional months of the Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen Retail Asset Management business in Q3 versus Q2. Net revenues increased $118.1 million or 20.1% quarter-over-quarter. The acquired business accounted for approximately $96 million of this increase, while favorable FX rates added about $8.1 million. Going down a little more deeply into that, you'll see that investment management fees grew by 14.7% or $95.7 million. And again, that was driven mostly by the contribution of the acquired business. FX contributed $11 million, while the Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen business contributed approximately $74 million. The remaining management fees earnings of $10.7 million was due to the positive impact of the markets on AUM relative to the second quarter.
Service and distribution revenues increased by $52.2 million or 37.4%, with the acquisition accounting for about $50 million of this variance. Performance fees declined $1 million to end at $2.5 million. Other revenues improved by $16.9 million relative to Q2. Again, driven largely by the two months more of the Van Kampen business in Q3. $14 million of the $16.9 million favorable variance was a result of new UIT issuance, which continues to run at a higher level than initially expected. The remaining $2.9 million increase is due to greater retained front-end loads, as well as due to transaction commissions from our Real Estate business.
Third-party distribution, service and advisory expense, which we net against gross revenues, increased by $45.7 million, with the VK/MS acquisition contributing approximately $42 million of it, and FX adding the remaining $3.9 million. Moving on the Slide, you'll see that our adjusted operating expenses at $461.3 million increased by $61 million or 15.2%. FX accounted for $5.4 million of this, which remainder largely being explained by the acquisition. Employee compensation expenses increased by $37.6 million or 14.5% versus the second quarter. The acquisition contributed to the majority of this variance, but we also had an increase in variable compensation, primarily bonus and sales commissions, in line with improving operating results in sales. And furthermore, we recognized $3.4 million of severance costs in Q3, which was $1.4 million less than what we recognized in Q2, and FX increased compensation expense by $3.7 million.
Marketing expense increased by $9.6 million or 27%. Again, largely due to the acquired business. Property, office and technology increased by 7.8% or 13.8% again for the same reason. G&A expenses came in at $54.3 million in the quarter, and was up $6 million versus the second quarter. FX added about $0.7 million, while the remaining $5.3 million in expense variance was explained equally by the impact of the acquisition, as well as a variety of other non-acquisition-related G&A expenses in the quarter. 
Continuing on down the page, you'll see that our effective tax rate on pretax adjusted cash net income in Q3 was unusually low relative to the other quarters, 23.1%, and in comparison to 29.3% in Q2. If you'll remember, however, this is in line with what happened in Q3 of 2009, and it's a function of our releasing the FIN 48 provisions for uncertain tax positions. What I would tell you is that going forward, this pattern of sharper lower tax rates in Q3 should subside as we don't expect to be releasing similarly large provisions in the future.
For Q4 2010, I'd say that we expect our effective tax rate on an adjusted basis to return to a more normalized ongoing level of about 29% to 30%. Before I move from this slide, I'll just point out that our adjusted EPS came in at $0.39, an increase of 44.4% versus Q2 and our adjusted net operating margin was 34.8%, improvements of 2.8 points versus Q2. So let me now shift gear. I'd like to provide an update on our progress towards achieving the cost synergy that we've discussed.
And moving to the next Slide, distinct from most other large transactions you've seen, we did take on imperatives to fully integrate the business essentially day one at the closing of the deal. And while this was a difficult challenge, it did set up the possibility for us to generate full cost synergies very quickly. And we mentioned in our Q2 release, after we closed the acquisition and simultaneously integrated the business, we'd no longer be able to track the Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen businesses expenses separately from Invesco. And with that in mind, it is still possible though to demonstrate that we're delivering the promised expense synergies
Our original estimated cost synergies of $80 million to $85 million in year one, I'd point out, were net of $50 million of reinvestment and marketing for our U.S. retail business. So excluding the impact of incremental marketing investment, the comparable growth year one costs synergy expectations is $95 million to $100 million. And the reason I'm saying this is, given the requisite lead time and planning, we've not yet begun investing the incremental $50 million in marketing. And so, we do expect to begin the investing at the end of 2010 or early 2011, with the pace of spend at roughly $3.7 million per quarter. What that means is, that for the Q3 results we discussed with you today, we would want to see growth annualized run rate synergies into $95 million to $100 million range and not the $80 million to $85 million range. So on this slide, we can demonstrate that we fully achieved the targeted annualized run rate of $95 million to $100 million of gross cost synergies and Q3, with the one caveat that, it's not a precise method since post integration as I've discussed, we're not able to track the MS/VK expenses separately. Let me take a moment to explain this table.
Column A on this table shows 2x the adjusted one month of operating expenses that the VK/MS acquisition contributed in June 2010, and we've showed that in the second quarter release. You'll recall that we've provided -- actually Column A, excuse me, represents the expected Q3 versus Q2 expense variance due to the acquired business assuming no further cost synergies were created relative to the June results. Column B on this table details out activity that contributed to Invesco's quarter-over-quarter variances, but were unrelated to that VK/MS and U.S. Retail business. And that includes foreign exchange and other identifiable variances such as severance, as I discussed, from our retooling of the U.S. institutional sales force increases in variable compensation, another known expense item from Invesco, specifically. Column C is the sum of A and B. And they represents the hypothetical Q3 versus Q2 expense variances, assuming no additional run rate synergies created during Q3 relative to the run rate embedded in June. But essentially, it assumes that in Q3, we operated the MS/VK business as in the same way we did in June. 
In Column B is the actual quarter-over-quarter adjusted operating expense variances result for the firm. so if you take the difference between D and C, that's what you'll find in Column E. That represents the incremental cost synergies we achieved during the third quarter relative to the second quarter, and Column F is truly the annualization of column A. So taking you through all that, in summary, subject to the caveat I mentioned earlier, this does show that we achieved an incremental $45.6 million in run rate annual cost synergies during Q3. If you add this to the $51 million, which represents the annualized run rate synergies we calculated in June, we've delivered a total annualized run rate of $96.6 million in Q3. And this amounted to squarely within our one year target of $95 million to $100 million in gross cost synergies which, of course, excludes the impact of the new marketing investments.
So again, a little bit of complicated table, but I hope it gives you comfort that we're on tract to deliver no less than what we projected in year one. And as we've discussed, we would expect to deliver at least another $10 million in savings at the end of year two after the U.S. fund range product rationalization has been completed. So with that, let me take a moment, turn to the next slide and talk about our capital management.
So our priorities remain consistent, no surprise. We will first look to reinvest our cash flow back into our business, followed by making acquisitions that would make strategic and financial sense. Thirdly, we wish to provide a moderately increasing dividend every year, approximately 46% annual growth. And then fourth would be opportunistic stock buybacks. We'll continue to operate these capital priorities against the foundation of maintaining a strong balance sheet. 
The new reality, post financial crisis is that our client and consultants require investment management firms that they work with to have a strong financial profile. In addition, for Invesco, a strong balance sheet provides us with the flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunity that could arise in the future. Therefore, as we've discussed in the past, our priority is to decrease the incremental leverage we took on at the close of the Morgan Stanley/Van Kampen transaction and pay off the $650 million of borrowing that's drawing on the credit facility. So despite this, though, we also told you not assume that our hands are completely tied with respect to buying back stocks and given where the stock was trading during the third quarter, coupled with our normal practice of eliminating dilution from deferred equity compensation, we did undertake to buy back $127.7 million of stock, equating to 6.4 million shares, at an average price of $19.82. And so as you saw this last quarter, we will continue to maintain an opportunistic stance with respect to stock buybacks.
So let me now turn it over to Marty.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Loren. So Loren and I are happy to answer any questions anybody might have.
componenttext: Thank you, Loren. So Loren and I are happy to answer any questions anybody might have.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question thus come from Ken Worthington of JPMC.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question thus come from Ken Worthington of JPMC.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on distribution. What kind of impact are you noticing thus far from LPO and Edward Jones in terms of retail sales? And then talk about the whole selling effort there. And then separately, more's on Van Kampen, you had been talking  a
componenttext: A couple of questions on distribution. What kind of impact are you noticing thus far from LPO and Edward Jones in terms of retail sales? And then talk about the whole selling effort there. And then separately, more's on Van Kampen, you had been talking  about elevating Van Kampen on various platforms. How is that going?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so just with the two organizations, obviously, very, very strong organizations. And Edward Jones continued to just be very strong. And probably, the reason is, as we matched off against Edward Jones, there was the fewest changes, right? So the leader
componenttext: Yes, so just with the two organizations, obviously, very, very strong organizations. And Edward Jones continued to just be very strong. And probably, the reason is, as we matched off against Edward Jones, there was the fewest changes, right? So the leadership on our side had not changed, the whole selling for us has really did not change at all. So we just continued to move forward from that point of view. So it continues to be a very strong relationship and as we mentioned earlier, there's a broader array of products now that Jones' has put on their platform and from the traditional Invesco part of the business. LPO, we are preferred partner right now, and literally just complete there it is a -- as you enter into new relationships like that, there's been a broad effort and I'd say, early days, but one of the highlights is that we completed, what I call sort of a client engagement plan, and receive the top marks within their system. So again, I'd say that's early days, but we expect that to be a very strong relationship going forward. And Ken, I'm sorry, what was third, the last one?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Van Kampen side, in discussions with platforms like Merrill Lynch and UBS to elevate the Van Kampen status there, how is that going? And I guess, over what time period do you think that starts to cease? And is it multiple quarters? Could we see som
componenttext: On the Van Kampen side, in discussions with platforms like Merrill Lynch and UBS to elevate the Van Kampen status there, how is that going? And I guess, over what time period do you think that starts to cease? And is it multiple quarters? Could we see something from either LPL or Van Kampen 4Q, 1Q or do think it takes longer than that?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, again, much of what I talked about earlier, I call them sort of medium indicators, right? So the broadening of funds on platforms is, I think, are prerequisite for ultimate success. And as I mentioned, yes, that's just improved quite dramatically
componenttext: I think, again, much of what I talked about earlier, I call them sort of medium indicators, right? So the broadening of funds on platforms is, I think, are prerequisite for ultimate success. And as I mentioned, yes, that's just improved quite dramatically. So Van Kampen on to some of the platforms that were less strong on that has gone very, very well. And if you look at other performance in the key areas, the U.S. value in particular, and the broader muni bond platform that we'd have know, very, very strong. I don't think you're going to see -- I think [indiscernible] what kind of closing you're going to see. It's all going to be fully dependent upon, really, when do investors start to look to U.S. value equity is and asset class. And what I do feel when that starts to happen, we're going to participate very, very nicely because it's just a very strong track record. And so I personally think, Ken, this is a multiple quarter effort, and the other reality is, that if you look at the performance, if you look at the depth and breadth of the organization, the platforms that are being accepted and the funds on to the different platforms, that's very, very good. We still have some work to do. We're a new name in the retail channels, I mean, that's a fundamental fact. So as I've said, if you put us against a firm that's been operating with a single name for 15 years in the channel, they'll run ahead of us out of the box. But I'd say we're making very, very good progress along the way to be a very, very important partner.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then for Loren, in the press release, you breakout net revenue yields before performance fees. Based on the world at September 30, so based on FX, equity market sales, et cetera, who does that yield look next quarter? Does it kind of start to cheat up
componenttext: And then for Loren, in the press release, you breakout net revenue yields before performance fees. Based on the world at September 30, so based on FX, equity market sales, et cetera, who does that yield look next quarter? Does it kind of start to cheat up? Does it cheat down? Can you just help us in direction there?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest driver of that will have to do with performance fees. But you're saying x performance fees, it will generally move up with the equity markets. So I would say given the fact that assets are somewhat higher, we will have that. Obviously, U
componenttext: Well, the biggest driver of that will have to do with performance fees. But you're saying x performance fees, it will generally move up with the equity markets. So I would say given the fact that assets are somewhat higher, we will have that. Obviously, UIT in passive [ph] could change a little of the mix. But I'd say generally with equity markets where they are and FX contributing, it should move marginally up.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I'm just going to add one more comment to Ken's question just to make the point, and as I was talking about, if you look at pre and post close, average gross flows being up 40%, which is quite, I think, dramatic in light of the markets we're in. And a
componenttext: And I'm just going to add one more comment to Ken's question just to make the point, and as I was talking about, if you look at pre and post close, average gross flows being up 40%, which is quite, I think, dramatic in light of the markets we're in. And also, the redemption rate dropping 12 percentage points. But it's really this broadening on the platforms in key client platforms and since June, we've seen a 250% increase, right? So that's a number of products that are being put in preferred position on platforms. So that's a very, very good start. But again, I don't think we're going to be satisfied until we get probably through next year.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question does come from Robert Lee of KBW.
componenttext: Our next question does come from Robert Lee of KBW.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just looking at compensation costs, I'm just curious, I mean, putting aside the transaction, are you seeing any kind of natant or building pressure on comp costs? You have had -- revenues have come back, earnings have come back, performance is good
componenttext: First, just looking at compensation costs, I'm just curious, I mean, putting aside the transaction, are you seeing any kind of natant or building pressure on comp costs? You have had -- revenues have come back, earnings have come back, performance is good. I would assume that for a lot of teams across the globe, maybe expectations are starting to kind of creep up again and competition for people, are you starting to see any kind of pressure there globally?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the reality is, I think you probably know, we have a very consistent compensation philosophy. And it's very, very clear. Plans in place, that sort of match performance and results around the investment teams do compensation levels. And so as the p
componenttext: I think the reality is, I think you probably know, we have a very consistent compensation philosophy. And it's very, very clear. Plans in place, that sort of match performance and results around the investment teams do compensation levels. And so as the performance continues to improve and as the business does better, our mechanism is such to reflect that. But I'd also say, we are very consistent because of that during the downturn, we have the ability also to use Invesco's stock and the products that investors invest in as long term deferrals. So I think our mechanism is very, very good and very consistent. And again, I think you have to go back to -- because we have thought through these things, I think it served us well during the downturn, and it will put us in a position to continue to report results. But I think the reality is as we do better, so we'll -- it's not just our shareholders, but also the organization.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question would be in understanding that a month isn't -- less so to make a trend or so, but could you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the new business trends broadly? Is breaking on institutional versus retail, I mean, since the end of
componenttext: Next question would be in understanding that a month isn't -- less so to make a trend or so, but could you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the new business trends broadly? Is breaking on institutional versus retail, I mean, since the end of the summer, and you find the market come back. Any signs in the retail wins? There's starting to be a little more activity. And then institutionally, I mean, how or where will you characterize kind of the strength in the RFP activity?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can chime in. So I think you have to look at the world in different ways and funnily enough, I think the U.S. retail world was uniquely impacted by the flash crash. And I think you saw that across. I'm sure,
componenttext: Maybe I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can chime in. So I think you have to look at the world in different ways and funnily enough, I think the U.S. retail world was uniquely impacted by the flash crash. And I think you saw that across. I'm sure, Robert, as you talked to some of the investment banks with distribution, I mean, they just literally went on strike. And so  you saw that. And I'd say what you're starting to see right now is, with the mutual funds and I think that is the area that was most impacted. Mutual funds, in particular, starting to get some confidence coming back a little bit in investors from that point of view. And probably, also moving up the risk curve a little bit as those people refer to as taking on risks. But I'd still say it's early. Where you did see it and what we saw, very much going into UITs and ETFs and that was a real positive, I'd say for us, and you probably saw that across the industry. But if you go to different parts of the world, whether it be Asia, or Europe or the United Kingdom, we had retail inflows in each of those areas. So it was not as impacted as the United States was. If you look at the institutional pipeline, it just continues to grow. And for us, the mandates tend to be -- continue to be very strong in real estate, continues to be very strong stable value. Also, some asset allocation capabilities that we have, premium thoughts  are really getting high degrees of interest. And so I'd say that's still a little more conservatively positioned than what we're seeing in the retail side of the business. And you do have some consultants that are actually very focused on fixed income and really limiting exposure to the equity market. And you can all pass our judgments whether or not we think that's the right asset allocation. But I suspect we're a lot closer to some people moving towards the equity side of the business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess to some degree, kind of money funds have kind of popped up a little bit again. I guess the president's counsel issued their report late last week. And I guess one of your peers in the side, they're going to take a small charge to kind of topple of
componenttext: I guess to some degree, kind of money funds have kind of popped up a little bit again. I guess the president's counsel issued their report late last week. And I guess one of your peers in the side, they're going to take a small charge to kind of topple off some money funds in advance of having to report shadow on NAVs on a delayed basis. I mean, any preliminary thoughts on takeaways from the president council's report on how you could be impacting or think about your money fund business? And then I guess the second thing would be, would you see any need to do a little top off of money funds, similar to what your competitors did?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. So first of all, I'd say from an industry point of view, the president's working through comments, and we're very consistent, I think, with what the industry was expecting to come out of it. From an inner perspective, we think we did a very, very g
componenttext: Right. So first of all, I'd say from an industry point of view, the president's working through comments, and we're very consistent, I think, with what the industry was expecting to come out of it. From an inner perspective, we think we did a very, very good job in the first round of changes, the money funds, and we think we have a very, very thoughtful next stage through the liquidity bank, which we think creates, again, a very compelling product as time goes on. So at an industry level, I think we're heading very much in the right direction. With regard to our own money funds, we don't have any -- we haven't had any problems with our money funds. They're very well run. We didn't have any boundaries or credits. We didn't have SIBs. None of those types of things. So it's probably those firms that had SIB-type exposure that might be having to look to do some top ups, and we don't have to do that. So from a specific company point of view, we are in a good spot.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question thus come from Michael Kim, Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question thus come from Michael Kim, Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just a follow-up on some of your comments earlier in terms of pension plans, maybe increasingly looking to immunize their liabilities. I guess the two takeaways that maybe are in play here. Just first, being that we could see a more permanent shift
componenttext: First, just a follow-up on some of your comments earlier in terms of pension plans, maybe increasingly looking to immunize their liabilities. I guess the two takeaways that maybe are in play here. Just first, being that we could see a more permanent shift in favor of low risk mandates. But then at the same time, maybe we see a step up in contributions just given the fact that a lot of these plans are still meaningfully underfunded. So just curious to get your take on that dynamic and then how that could potentially impact your business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we can make some broad comments, but the fundamental fact it's got to be the company by company because we're all in different spots. And the notion of immunizing your portfolio at the bottom of the market cycle, too me, doesn't seem very wise. So
componenttext: I think we can make some broad comments, but the fundamental fact it's got to be the company by company because we're all in different spots. And the notion of immunizing your portfolio at the bottom of the market cycle, too me, doesn't seem very wise. So the combination of some firms that are able to get contributions, which we saw just from the last week or two, we saw some of those. I personally believe you're going to see some equity exposure go against that. It's very hard to close that by immunizing your portfolio. Just mathematically, you can't do it. But that doesn't mean that you won't see some firms that are fully funded or close to it that would takes some risks off the table by immunizing their portfolio. So the reality is, And I think where all of us see road to retirement growth, it's going to be in the DC world. But there is a tremendous amount of assets in the BB world right now. And I still think the merits of a well-balanced portfolio to deliver results are going to make sense. And maybe once funds are fully funded, and they can offset the liability, you'll see a massive immunization trend. But I personally can't imagine that right now considering the market cycle we came out of and when we're likely to go into.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then kind of maybe turning to the retail side of the story, as we look across the industry, it does seem like flows remain pretty concentrated in a relatively limited number products that either have strong performance or maybe are filling a particula
componenttext: And then kind of maybe turning to the retail side of the story, as we look across the industry, it does seem like flows remain pretty concentrated in a relatively limited number products that either have strong performance or maybe are filling a particular strategy. What are some specific funds at Invesco that you think can really become market share leaders going forward, if and when we do get this reallocation back into equities?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe one I'd do if by category, instead of fund by fund. I mean, I think the fundamental fact is, we you pointed out a few quarters ago, and if you're asking specifically about the United States, our equity line up is very, very strong. And if you l
componenttext: Yes, maybe one I'd do if by category, instead of fund by fund. I mean, I think the fundamental fact is, we you pointed out a few quarters ago, and if you're asking specifically about the United States, our equity line up is very, very strong. And if you look at U.S. value, U.S. core, international growth, it's about a competitive as you're going to find out there. And if you look within our Fixed Income lineup, the Muni Bond line up, we think is very, very strong. The bank loan group is very, very strong. Those are things that are probably going to continue through a market cycle. I think many of us would be expecting probably the pressure on tax rates, which makes muni bonds attractive and bank loans in high-yield as another area where we're quite strong, I think, even in the pricing interest-rate environment, they'll continue to be attractive. So the broad category is, I think we line up very, very nicely. And if you look at the growth line ups, small-cap growth is very strong, and large cap growth, we actually have more recently added a very strong growth team leadership, we feel very good about that also. So it is broad.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just a final question for Loren, it seems like you've had a nice bounce here in margins, and you're kind of running just shy of maybe the 35% to 40% range that you've talked about in the past. So assuming we continued to get cooperative mar
componenttext: And then maybe just a final question for Loren, it seems like you've had a nice bounce here in margins, and you're kind of running just shy of maybe the 35% to 40% range that you've talked about in the past. So assuming we continued to get cooperative markets, it seems like you've got some tail winds here whether it's an improving mix or further efficiencies and just kind of natural leverage in the model. So do you feel like you can get closer to kind of that the high end of that range, maybe a bit quicker than you might have expected previously?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Michael, again, just to tell you, we don't have any specific margin targets. So we will obviously move in line with equity markets and general markets. But I think the reality is that, clearly, you saw the impact of the acquisition was very helpf
componenttext: I think, Michael, again, just to tell you, we don't have any specific margin targets. So we will obviously move in line with equity markets and general markets. But I think the reality is that, clearly, you saw the impact of the acquisition was very helpful for improving margins and the idea that we could be in the high 30s in a short period do seems quite feasible if we maintain sort of levels of assets where we are today. So again, I think its certainly, in line of sight for us.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question does come from Craig Siegenthaler of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question does come from Craig Siegenthaler of Credit Suisse.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on Michael's last question, the expense reductions. How big of a driver is the fund mergers in 4Q and 1Q relative to the future expense synergies? Is that basically all of it?
componenttext: Just a follow-up on Michael's last question, the expense reductions. How big of a driver is the fund mergers in 4Q and 1Q relative to the future expense synergies? Is that basically all of it?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: There is no real expense reduction and 4Q and 1Q due to the mergers. The mergers will actually take place some time or it could be the end of the first quarter, sometimes the second quarter. So there's an extra $10 million of expenses that would come out
componenttext: There is no real expense reduction and 4Q and 1Q due to the mergers. The mergers will actually take place some time or it could be the end of the first quarter, sometimes the second quarter. So there's an extra $10 million of expenses that would come out at that point in time, but all of the expense reductions that you've seen to date are really a result of just taking on the business on our operating platforms and facilities and all the things we've talked about in the past.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: To add, just on the timing point of view, it seems it'd be very late first quarter. I think you should probably think more likely first half of second quarter, but again, the reason why we can't be more specific as we saw last time, that means, there's no
componenttext: To add, just on the timing point of view, it seems it'd be very late first quarter. I think you should probably think more likely first half of second quarter, but again, the reason why we can't be more specific as we saw last time, that means, there's notable approvals and probably the hardest one that takes least predictable is the individual shareholder approvals.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then with the timing there, should we really think about that $5 billion of kind of net redemptions driven by the kind of the product mergers here? Should that really be a 1Q and 2Q event not really as much a 4Q event?
componenttext: And then with the timing there, should we really think about that $5 billion of kind of net redemptions driven by the kind of the product mergers here? Should that really be a 1Q and 2Q event not really as much a 4Q event?

componenttext: Greg, it depends again on when ultimately we'll get approval for the transactions that are being proposed. If they're accepted by the fund boards, they'll are actually be information out this quarter through the stickering of the funds that would perhaps begin some of the outflow at that point. So it could be somewhat in the fourth quarter as well.

componenttext: Glenn Schorr of UBS.

componenttext: One is just a reminder on the geography of cash U.S. versus U.K. and how that plays a role in your detailed cash mentioned update slide in terms of buybacks, pay down of credit facility and such?

componenttext: In terms of the firm's cash, in had about $460 million of cash in what we call the European subgroup, it's not just the U.K., it's really cash that can be used throughout Europe out of the total of $664 million.

componenttext: The $204 million, which is net adds is available for that type of activity, correct.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Loren, maybe just one other number question. What do you have in the way of funds or assets under management with performance fees attached? And is fourth quarter the bigger strike date or is that first quarter?
componenttext: And then, Loren, maybe just one other number question. What do you have in the way of funds or assets under management with performance fees attached? And is fourth quarter the bigger strike date or is that first quarter?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: The total amount of assets under management with performance fees is roughly $20 billion to $25 billion. It's probably closer to $20 billion. The fourth quarter/first quarter phenomenon that you've seen in the past in terms of performance fees have typica
componenttext: The total amount of assets under management with performance fees is roughly $20 billion to $25 billion. It's probably closer to $20 billion. The fourth quarter/first quarter phenomenon that you've seen in the past in terms of performance fees have typically been driven through the U.K. I think we've said in the past, that we weren't expecting performance fees in the fourth quarter from the U.K. And, again, it's a point-in-time calculation, so it's something that we typically find very difficult to forecast. And so I would still suggest to you that you should not assume that we're going to see anything large coming from the U.K. in the fourth quarter. There may be some performance fees from some other parts of our business coming in the fourth quarter as we've always seen some parts of the business having some level of performance fees. But probably nothing dramatic.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cynthia Mayer of Bank of America.
componenttext: Cynthia Mayer of Bank of America.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could give a little color on the other revenues, maybe give a breakout of what that was? Was there increase versus last quarter, the two extra months of UIT fees and FX, or was there something else in there?
componenttext: Wondering if you could give a little color on the other revenues, maybe give a breakout of what that was? Was there increase versus last quarter, the two extra months of UIT fees and FX, or was there something else in there?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, Cynthia, the total increase in other revenues was $16.9 million and of that, again, and there's -- $14.4 million was a result of new UIT issuance. Now if you'll remember, in June, there was $5.5 million of UIT revenues. So the $14 million difference i
componenttext: So, Cynthia, the total increase in other revenues was $16.9 million and of that, again, and there's -- $14.4 million was a result of new UIT issuance. Now if you'll remember, in June, there was $5.5 million of UIT revenues. So the $14 million difference is showing that we are at a much higher run rate than we were at June. But it's really driven by -- the $14 million driven by UITs and there was $2.9 million that was a result of more a traditional Invesco-related business, real estate transactions and front-end loads.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Since the UIT issuance is running at a higher rate that you expected, what is driving that? And what's your outlook for that? And how profitable is that business?
componenttext: Since the UIT issuance is running at a higher rate that you expected, what is driving that? And what's your outlook for that? And how profitable is that business?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, again, it's being driven by, I think, interest in the product itself, which is tax efficient, very transparent. It is one of these products that I think, appeals to many individuals, who are looking to buying and hold. And it is something that I
componenttext: I think, again, it's being driven by, I think, interest in the product itself, which is tax efficient, very transparent. It is one of these products that I think, appeals to many individuals, who are looking to buying and hold. And it is something that I think we've seen the expansion of UITs go beyond where they traditionally were within the Morgan Stanley network as they've start to become part of the broader Invesco network. And so I think that's also another contributing in factor to the success. But they are a leader in the industry and it is something that I think we feel that we can do a lot with. Fixed income has been a very big part of the interest in the UIT side. The Build America Bonds piece but interestingly and more recently, equities have been factored into that mix as well now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you update us on the outlook for acquisition-related outflows and give us a sense for what impact they had this quarter and what flows would have been without them?
componenttext: Can you update us on the outlook for acquisition-related outflows and give us a sense for what impact they had this quarter and what flows would have been without them?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rights. Well, Cynthia, we would say that the acquisition-related outflows are going to really be a function of the product mergers and the announcements of the product mergers, which have not happened yet. So we would not attribute any of the $5 billion t
componenttext: Rights. Well, Cynthia, we would say that the acquisition-related outflows are going to really be a function of the product mergers and the announcements of the product mergers, which have not happened yet. So we would not attribute any of the $5 billion that we've originally discussed to this quarter or prior quarters. We think the $5 billion is still  a number that we were guiding people to that would begin once the information is out there. We're still hopeful that it's less than that, but given kind of our analysis, we think that $5 billion could be the case. So we think that would be centered around the fourth quarter, starting in the fourth quarter, and assuming the approval takes place and continuing on to the first and the second quarters of 2011.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, can you tell us what there was in the way of fee waivers in the quarter and also what the ending share count was?
componenttext: Finally, can you tell us what there was in the way of fee waivers in the quarter and also what the ending share count was?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Fee waivers were never a major factor for us, Cynthia, because we have it in the Money Market business. So if there is any number in there, it's probably under $5 million in terms of fee waivers, so it's not a significant component. In terms of ending sha
componenttext: Fee waivers were never a major factor for us, Cynthia, because we have it in the Money Market business. So if there is any number in there, it's probably under $5 million in terms of fee waivers, so it's not a significant component. In terms of ending share count, it was 474.3 million.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next question does come from Dan Fannon of Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question does come from Dan Fannon of Jefferies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010

componenttext: Marty, could you maybe expand upon the comments about the product placement increase of roughly 250%, sequentially? Kind of let us know where we are in that process and we should still see increased penetration or more products being placed? Then going forward, or are we kind of done the majority of that already?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Look, I think you have to look at it as, one, an immediate jump out of the box at Edward Jones, being an important part of that. And then a couple of the others. But we don't think we're done, right? And we think it's literally going to be all of next yea
componenttext: Look, I think you have to look at it as, one, an immediate jump out of the box at Edward Jones, being an important part of that. And then a couple of the others. But we don't think we're done, right? And we think it's literally going to be all of next year before we hit that sort of state that we think is sort of a more normal state. But it's -- in one of the questions earlier was, just around LPL. We have very strong relationship, very strong planning phase out of the box. But that's different than getting the depth of product that you want on the platforms, and it is just a lot of work as everybody knows. It's really no different than trying to get by ratings and consultant platforms. And so I'd say we're early days of where we want to get to.

componenttextpreview: And would some of that increase be attributable to Morgan Stanley and Smith Barney, also having a bigger exposure there as well?
componenttext: And would some of that increase be attributable to Morgan Stanley and Smith Barney, also having a bigger exposure there as well?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's absolutely a part of it, yes.
componenttext: That's absolutely a part of it, yes.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question does come from William Katz of Citi.
componenttext: The next question does come from William Katz of Citi.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to come back to your margin opportunity again, Loren. By your existing right, you mentioned that the fee rate might tick up a little bit marginally if equities continue from where equities are today, I guess. And you've gotten the bulk of the
componenttext: I just want to come back to your margin opportunity again, Loren. By your existing right, you mentioned that the fee rate might tick up a little bit marginally if equities continue from where equities are today, I guess. And you've gotten the bulk of the cost saves and from the conversations, it seems like retail leverage is probably more of a 2012 phenomenon. Can you just help me walk through how you get that extra 700 basis points of margin improvement from here all else being equal?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, it's the same things that have allowed us to, in the past, generate higher margins where if equities grow, it's the higher fee rate part of our mix. There's certainly some amount of compensation that gets built up against those revenues. But in
componenttext: Obviously, it's the same things that have allowed us to, in the past, generate higher margins where if equities grow, it's the higher fee rate part of our mix. There's certainly some amount of compensation that gets built up against those revenues. But incremental margins, as we've discussed, they're somewhere 60%, and in's that range. So you can generate higher margins just through that extension. I think the other parts of the business to the extent that we're able to continue the positive trend on sales and organic growth is going to be helpful for profitability, particularly if we're selling higher fee products which, again, if they're equities, they are sort of coming into light, I think we would benefit from that as well. So there's one more element in the mix, not a major one, we've talked about in the past as we continue to transition to our enterprise support centers in low cost locations given there's some elements of margin expansion that's good to take place there and we are looking at taking on our India operation to our books some time in early part of next year and there's going to be some cost benefits to that as well.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Marty, you mentioned before about just sort of the president's working group, might read up [ph] a day so I came up with seven or eight different alternatives, that really didn't have any solutions within those that the passing on to the episode [ph] seat
componenttext: Marty, you mentioned before about just sort of the president's working group, might read up [ph] a day so I came up with seven or eight different alternatives, that really didn't have any solutions within those that the passing on to the episode [ph] seat as we take a look at. But you mentioned a little more clarity maybe the possibility of liquidity bank. And so I'm curious, is that the most likely scenario in your mind in terms of all the optionality that they've identified.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's see. So let me answer this way, so I said, our absolute understanding consistently was that the president's working group was going to lay a bunch of options, the pros and cons along those, and that's what happened. The liquidity bank from my point
componenttext: Let's see. So let me answer this way, so I said, our absolute understanding consistently was that the president's working group was going to lay a bunch of options, the pros and cons along those, and that's what happened. The liquidity bank from my point of view, and I think the industry's point of view really is a very, very constructive, powerful thing that helps meet a primary goal that's trying to be achieved by the president's working group. And so I'd say from our perspective, we think it's the more the likely outcome just because it achieves, and our goals have been set up by the president's working group.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question, you mentioned that your retail is going to take a little while to swing its full run rate, but yet on a sequential basis, your gross sales did pop and your redemptions did as slow. Can you talk a little bit about, and maybe answer maybe [ph
componenttext: Last question, you mentioned that your retail is going to take a little while to swing its full run rate, but yet on a sequential basis, your gross sales did pop and your redemptions did as slow. Can you talk a little bit about, and maybe answer maybe [ph] these UITs and EPS, but what you're seeing in terms of lift sequentially that's giving you the balance in the growth sales?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: My answer is sort of two questions, right? So what we try to point out just by giving some pre-close, post close month-over-month gross sales redemptions in that close, but we are literally trying to show showing out-of-the-box, and you see, again, it's o
componenttext: My answer is sort of two questions, right? So what we try to point out just by giving some pre-close, post close month-over-month gross sales redemptions in that close, but we are literally trying to show showing out-of-the-box, and you see, again, it's only four months, a 40% -- five months, a 40% average increase month-over-month in gross flows. So the messages is, strong out-of-the-box impact already. But I think the next question that I was hearing was, are we done? And the answer is, no, we're not done at all. And we think getting through next year is, my view, we'll as [ph] just still see a continuation of broadening importance to important counter parties during that period of time. So again, where we saw a lot of the flows is really -- UITs were very important during this period largely around Fixed Income. We're equities coming through right now in UITs, as Loren mentioned earlier. ETFs was very strong. But again, we're seeing just a much broader penetration here within the channel that we're in. So I think? we're strong out-of-the-box and then we'll of get stronger.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question does come from Michael Carrier of Deutsche Bank.

componenttext: Marty, can you talk a little bit about now as you enter Phase II just sort of what the new business product opportunities are for you, sort of combining some of your capabilities? When you think about the opportunities sort of going out, some of the wide spaces out there you don't have today, how do you think your -- how do you sort of plan to move forward in terms of product?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our review is, once we -- starting in the U.S., once we -- so if you look at the depth and breadth of the product, quality of our product, we feel very, very good. And its lead by our investment management team. And we think they're very, very strong. And
componenttext: Our review is, once we -- starting in the U.S., once we -- so if you look at the depth and breadth of the product, quality of our product, we feel very, very good. And its lead by our investment management team. And we think they're very, very strong. And so the next phase in the United States, on the retail side, is just cleaning up the lineup, which we we've sort of dwelled on today. But if you look at the separate, distinct and best management teams, the quality of the team's performance, it's not just the United States, but outside the United States. We've started to talk about Asia for a second. We find that to be very, very attractive for us. But quite frankly, our European business, where the top 10 Pan-European players, we think there is much greater scope for us to be impactful than Europe and though again our attention continues to look at where the historical strengths of this firm and that's outside of the United States. And we don't feel that we're -- there's lots of white space. There's always room for improvement with what we have. But at the moment, it's all looking quite strong for us.

componenttext: I know this is probably a little bit further out, but I think some of your capital priorities include acquisitions. Where, Loren, can you talk some of the criteria? And then Marty, maybe from a scope perspective, would you be looking at these days?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: The criteria that we've discussed in the past, a financial -- well, first, its strategic. We wanted to be a strategic acquisition. We don't like generally like to do Passive sort of types of acquisition. I don't think we've got any that are sort of just b
componenttext: The criteria that we've discussed in the past, a financial -- well, first, its strategic. We wanted to be a strategic acquisition. We don't like generally like to do Passive sort of types of acquisition. I don't think we've got any that are sort of just buying assets for the sake of growing. So it's going to complement the business, add the capability that we don't have as an example. The financial criteria would be IRRs in excess of 20%. we like a cash payback within seven years, and we also like to see the deal be accretive from day one. Its a combination of those two things that will generally give us a sense of comfort. That's how we can move ahead financially. Marty, I don't know if you want to talk about...

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010

componenttext: No, I'd be here [ph] pretty well. And just from where we are, there is nothing -- even if we -- as I said, we just don't sense that we have gaps, and we think our greatest utility for our clients and shareholders's to put our head down and do a very, very good job of what we have.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping that you guys could talk a little bit more about the UITs. Is this roughly $5 million per month run rate, sort of the right way to think about it? And then or were there any specific issuance that skewed the quarter? And also talk about the m
componenttext: I was hoping that you guys could talk a little bit more about the UITs. Is this roughly $5 million per month run rate, sort of the right way to think about it? And then or were there any specific issuance that skewed the quarter? And also talk about the margins on this business?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brennan, so in terms of the run rate, obviously, June was at a $5.5 million. I think we've suggested that we're moving at a higher run rate even this quarter with about $14 million differential, so call it $6 million to $7 million. I think, again, the pro
componenttext: Brennan, so in terms of the run rate, obviously, June was at a $5.5 million. I think we've suggested that we're moving at a higher run rate even this quarter with about $14 million differential, so call it $6 million to $7 million. I think, again, the profitability on these products are pretty well set by the industry standards in terms of what the sales charges are and what's retained . So there's nothing specific about any one UIT or any particular type of UIT that we're generating that's as creating this. I think the other thing to note , the number of UITs are significant. It's not one big UIT, it's many, many different ones being continually launched throughout the course of the quarter. So it's a portfolio. And as there's a particular UIT sort of comes to maturity, we have the opportunity to create a new one and put those the clients into a new UIT. And so it is sort of a self perpetuating, very positive cycle. The profitability is very strong. It's margins' at the higher end of the range of the types of businesses that we have. So it's a very good business for us financially, and it's one that I think, we do believe, have some opportunity even outside of the U.S. at some point. Obviously, regulatory barriers may still exist. That would not allow us to bring it to bring it to different countries, but we are looking at that as well

componenttext: And how many there are your customers? I mean, is it pretty much all of them just hurry up [ph] (1.21.17) for the new UIT when it expires? componenttext: Yes. In terms of the actual -- how successful we are re-upping that, I actually don't have that information, but you are correct about the Fixed Income product. They tend to be in excess of five years, five to 10, even 15 years or so. Once they're in, in one of those, they're in for a longer period of time.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you can't say a lot about where we're off Fund V. Can you just remind us historically about Fund IV, when it was closed and then sort of historically, how long does it take these funds to get seasoned and potentially qualify for performance fees on
componenttext: I know you can't say a lot about where we're off Fund V. Can you just remind us historically about Fund IV, when it was closed and then sort of historically, how long does it take these funds to get seasoned and potentially qualify for performance fees on sort of a look-forward basis?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Fund IV closed in the end of 2007 and $4 billion, there were two closes as part of that, one, in the third quarter, one in the fourth quarter. And in terms of the timing around performance fees or the carrier that we were receiving, it's hard to obviou
componenttext: So Fund IV closed in the end of 2007 and $4 billion, there were two closes as part of that, one, in the third quarter, one in the fourth quarter. And in terms of the timing around performance fees or the carrier that we were receiving, it's hard to obviously predict and has everything to do with how quickly things get invested get then harvested and that has a lot to do with the current market environment. I think for Fund IV, it did not get invested as quickly as maybe some of the other funds have been for given their market, it was prudent to wait and probably smarter to have done that. And We have, obviously, been waiting for it to get to 75% invested because we could not launch another fund until that happens. In terms of the harvesting period, I think it's still going to be several years to be thinking about of the timing before we actually see a performance fee. It's above our hurdle too, so you need to generate, I think, it's 8.5% hurdle rate, generally. So I would guide a couple of years before you begin o to think about  performance fees for Fund IV.

componenttext: Well, we have our own models. We also look at ourselves relative to competitors, as you'd imagine. And so when we see that the market is not giving us value for certainly this acquisition as a good example of something where saw a disconnect, we felt very good about our ability to go in and buy in this stuff at a lower price.
